source.title: Crane Brake Failure and Loss of Primary Containment - Noble Stanley Lafosse

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, GC Block 478

event.incident_type: Crane brake failure during load testing with hydraulic fluid release
actions_taken: Load test stopped immediately
OIM, DSL, and STS notified
Announcement made warning of slick decks from hydraulic fluid
Pipe rack barriered off to prevent slip hazards
Scupper plugs installed in drains to isolate LOPC
Water bag recovery attempted
Crane placed in cradle
Inspection of brakes, motor, and crane cable by contractor and two third party crane companies
BSEE Houma District office notified orally and written report submitted within 15 days
event.summary: On May 2, 2024, during 5-year recertification load testing of forward starboard knuckle boom crane (KBC #1) on the drillship Noble Stanley Lafosse at GC 478, a winch brake assembly failure occurred at approximately 70 MT while attempting to reach 93.5 MT test load. The crane's Automatic Overload Protection System (AOPS) activated, but brake assembly #4 failed to release simultaneously with the other three brakes. This caused excessive load on the sprag clutches which sheared, resulting in uncontrolled descent of the water bag. The descent caused a hydraulic test port failure, spraying hydraulic fluid on deck (LOPC). The water bag contacted the take-on station, ripped open, and descended to the Gulf of Mexico. Two hydraulic motors and four brake assemblies were damaged. Total property damage was $168,150. No injuries occurred.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District has no recommendations at this time
key_phrases: brake assemblies did not release simultaneously

hazards.name: Pressurized hydraulic fluid in crane system

threats.name: Brake assembly failure during load test
AOPS activation with non-simultaneous brake release
Sprag clutch overload and shear
Crane overload due to incorrect sea lift area configuration
Inadequate procedure for load testing over vessel side

consequences.name: Loss of Primary Containment - hydraulic fluid release
Slip hazard from hydraulic fluid on deck
Loss of water bag to Gulf of Mexico

source.title: Structural Damage - Injury During Slip and Cut Drill Line Operations

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Keathley Canyon Block 785

event.incident_type: Personnel Injury - Slip/Trip/Fall with Struck By

event.summary: On 7 March 2024 at 1500 hours, a Seadrill employee sustained a back and shoulder injury during slip and cut drill line operations on the Seadrill West Neptune drillship. While attempting to correct an abnormal twist in a 2-inch diameter drill line using an air tugger and nylon web sling, the drill line slipped from the sling and fell approximately 20-25 feet. The 19-foot section weighing 148 pounds struck the employee who had tripped while exiting the line of fire, hitting his hardhat, rolling over his middle back and left shoulder. He was diagnosed with a torn labrum and required 10-12 weeks of physical therapy.

event.summary: On July 8, 2024, while pulling out of the hole with drill pipe on the jack-up rig Enterprise 205, the traveling block struck the crown saver assembly with approximately 117,000 lbs overpull, resulting in $11,210 in damages. The driller lost situational awareness while checking the pipe tally, and the crown-o-matic (COM) failed to trip when contacted by the drill line because the barrel wasn't set properly. Contributing factors included inadequate hazard analysis in the JSA, lack of rig-specific procedures for checking the COM, and failure of floorhand to count tool joints during the operation.

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Structural Damage/Injury - Green Canyon Block 432

context.region: Gulf of America, Green Canyon Block 432

actions_taken: IP stabilized by medic

event.summary: On November 10, 2024, at 0145 hours, an injured person (IP) was struck by a wave on the stern of the Transocean Deepwater Invictus drillship during workover operations. Despite being informed during a pre-tour meeting that the stern was secured due to deteriorating weather and building seas (approximately 15-foot waves), the IP entered the restricted area to observe the water. A wave struck the IP, throwing him approximately 20 feet across the rig, causing him to strike a bollard before coming to rest at the base of a stairwell. The IP sustained a fractured right femur and was evacuated to West Jefferson Hospital. The investigation concluded that the IP's failure to observe the secured area and follow supervisor direction contributed significantly to the accident.
recommendations: Determine if there should be restricted areas on the rig during adverse weather conditions and communicate these locations to all personnel during pre-tour and other relevant meetings
Assess helideck capabilities and challenges for landing under adverse weather conditions
Place additional restricted access signs around the rig as needed, based on weather-related restrictions
Conduct a safety meeting for each tour when significant adverse weather is present with focus on adverse weather awareness
BSEE recommends issuing a safety alert/bulletin regarding this incident

source.title: Structural Damage - Lifeboat Manual Winch Incident

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - High Island Area Block A-5

event.summary: On July 11, 2024, at approximately 0730 hours, during a routine life capsule inspection at the High Island A-5 Manta Ray Gathering Facility, a contract pipeline operator from Quality Process Services suffered a serious head injury when struck by a winch assist handle. The Genesis Person in Charge and the injured person lowered the capsule 4 to 6 feet to verify winch operations. After lowering, the PIC engaged the electric winch from the lower section to raise the capsule. The winch assist handle, which should have been removed before operating the electric winch, remained in the socket. As the winch operated, the handle struck the IP in the head, causing him to fall unconscious with head bleeding. A safety device designed to prevent winch operation with the handle in place had been bypassed. The IP was diagnosed with a fractured skull requiring surgery. The incident was attributed to inadequate knowledge of equipment operation and failure to follow safety protocols, with contributing factors including lack of Job Safety Analysis and improper equipment handling.
recommendations: Conduct onsite training for all operators by contract survival craft specialists
Develop JSHA to address safety concerns related to routine tasks including winch operations
Conduct thorough review of operational procedures and checklists to ensure all necessary safety measures are included

source.title: Structural Damage - Crane Stinger Failure

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Ship Shoal Block 189

actions_taken: Shut down all operations
Barricaded affected areas

event.summary: On March 13, 2024, during plug and abandon operations on jack-up rig Enterprise 264, a crane stinger failed while offloading a 4x40 foot basket weighing 13,000 pounds from a workboat. The stinger, rated for 9.80 tons vertical pull, parted due to internal corrosion from moisture buildup in the socket over time. The basket fell upside down onto the control room, P-tanks, and platform on top of living quarters, causing approximately $7,500 in damage. No injuries occurred. Investigation revealed that the stinger had not been specifically inspected prior to use, and inspection procedures (Preventive Maintenance Daily checklist, cold work permit, and JSA) did not explicitly require stinger inspection.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Caught Between Incident During Casing Offload

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Walker Ridge Block 29

actions_taken: Crane operator safely landed the bundle of casing
IP attended to by rig medic
IP evacuated via medevac to hospital in greater New Orleans area
BSEE Houma District office notified orally and written report submitted in eWell within 15 days
BSEE onsite investigation conducted on March 7, 2024
event.summary: On February 16, 2024, during crane operations offloading 16-inch casing from a supply vessel to the pipe deck on the Nabors MODS 400 rig, a deck foreman (IP) was struck by a swinging bundle of casing weighing approximately 11,500 lbs. The IP had turned his back to the suspended load while verifying casing tally and failed to recognize he was positioned in the impact zone between the casing bundle and a sub-rack basket. Despite warnings from riggers, the bundle struck the IP on the right hip, forcing his left hip into the sub-rack basket, resulting in three pelvic fractures. The IP was evacuated to hospital and discharged four days later.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Structural Damage - 22 inch Casing Parting

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Green Canyon Block 478

actions_taken: Investigation committee formed on January 19, 2024
Recovery operations initiated
Well successfully plugged on February 11, 2024
Casing recovered on February 11, 2024
BSEE issued immediate preservation order for all equipment and casing
Metallurgical testing of casing connections performed
event.summary: On January 18, 2024, while running 22 inch casing on the drillship Noble Stanley Lafosse at GC 478 Well 004, the S-90/MT connection between joints 16 and 17 failed due to cross-threading. When the slips were opened to install anti-rotation keys, 72 joints of casing fell partially into the hole and onto the seafloor, impacting subsea infrastructure. The connection was made up only 1/4 to 3/8 turn instead of the required 1/2 to 3/4 turn, and visual inspection failed to detect a 0.143 inch gap indicating cross-threading. No injuries or environmental impacts occurred, but damages exceeded $15 million.

hazards.name: Suspended Load - 72 Joints of 22 inch Casing

threats.name: Cross-threaded casing connection
Inadequate makeup turns (1/4 to 3/8 turn vs required 1/2 to 3/4 turn)
Premature opening of slips before connection verification
Change in work process after crew change

consequences.name: Damage to intervention panel and MPFM
Potential catastrophic oil release from flowing wells

controls.barrier_role: Verification of proper connection makeup
controls.lod_basis: Independent verification step

supporting_text: the contractor's rig-site rep did not complete a visual inspection of the makeup as per the approved contractor's running procedure, missing an approximately 0.143 inch gap between the pin indicator and box connection
If a visual inspection of the connection was performed the evidence of cross threading could have been noticed

controls.name: Makeup turn verification procedure (1/2 to 3/4 turn requirement)
controls.barrier_role: Ensure proper connection engagement
controls.lod_basis: Primary operational control

supporting_text: Murphy's primary root cause for the event was the casing only making up 1/4 - 3/8 turn instead of 1/2 - 3/4 turn as specified by the contractor's procedures for proper make up
A review of still pictures from the rig video indicated that the connection rotated only 1/4 - 3/8 turn during the makeup, instead of the 1/2 - 3/4 turn specified in the contractor's procedure

controls.name: Contractor onsite representative verification
controls.barrier_role: Independent oversight and verification
controls.lod_basis: Independent verification by specialist

supporting_text: The contractor's onsite representative failed to identify this discrepancy
the second probable cause is the Contractor's onsite reps failing to verify the connection before the slips were released

controls.name: Pre-job safety meeting (PJSM)

controls.lod_basis: Pre-task planning and communication

supporting_text: On January 17, 2024, at 04:00 hours, a pre-job safety meeting (PJSM) is held with crews on running 22 inch casing

controls.barrier_role: Define proper sequence of operations
controls.lod_basis: Primary procedural control

supporting_text: After looking through the JSA and the Contractor's running procedure we could not find supporting documents showing if the anti-rotation keys are to be installed before the slips are opened
the last probable cause was the JSA and running procedure failing to identify when to install the anti-rotation keys

controls.name: Supervisor verification before slip release
controls.barrier_role: Final verification before critical operation
controls.lod_basis: Supervisory oversight

supporting_text: A contributing cause to this incident was the Contractor trainee signaling for the casing to be repositioned without the Contractor supervisor verifying the connection is made up properly
The contractor's trainee signal for the casing to be repositioned in the slips without the Contractor's supervisor verifying the connection

controls.barrier_role: Physical support to prevent casing drop
controls.lod_basis: Primary load-bearing device

supporting_text: The flush-mounted slips holding joint 17 were temporary opened to lower the connection to install two vertical anti-rotation keys in the connection. When the slips opened, the axial load of the 22 inch was transferred to the connection, the pin separated from the box, resulting in the casing parting at the rig floor

supporting_text: A review of still pictures from the rig video indicated that the connection rotated only 1/4 - 3/8 turn during the makeup

source.title: Dropped Drill Pipe Incident - Thunder Horse PDQ Platform

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Mississippi Canyon Block 778

event.top_event: Loss of Containment of Suspended Load
actions_taken: Job was stopped and area secured

event.summary: On February 18, 2023, at 21:27 hours, while pulling out of the hole with the 13th stand of 4-1/2 inch drill pipe on the Thunder Horse PDQ Platform, the Driller opened the BX4 elevator before the Pipe Racking System (PRS) could secure the stand. This caused the stand of drill pipe to fall across the rig floor towards the port side, landing on the auxiliary PRS hoist. Three Floor Hands in the yellow zone evacuated the area, with one slipping on the deck and injuring his knee and hip. The Floor Hand was evacuated the next day for medical evaluation. The incident could have resulted in multiple fatalities. Investigation revealed the Driller had a similar incident on January 3, 2023, and was not following Work Instructions WI-TH-DR-OPS-096.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Platform Gail Conductor Removal Injury

context.region: Pacific OCS Region - Lease P00205, Area/Block LA/6012

event.top_event: Loss of Containment of Human Body Part
actions_taken: Operations stopped immediately
First aid administered by medic
Injured person evacuated by boat to shore
Amputated digits recovered and transported with injured person
Ambulance transport to Ventura hospital
Work placed on stand down immediately after incident
Incident reported to BSEE Regional Supervisor via email same day
BSEE onsite investigation conducted June 19, 2023
Operations recommenced July 7, 2023 using chain-link fence fabric method
event.summary: On June 18, 2023, at approximately 18:35, an amputation injury occurred during decommissioning operations at Platform Gail. The injured person was adjusting chains in a marine growth removal system when a conductor began rising unexpectedly. The injured person had requested an 'all stop' and seeing movement stop, placed his left hand fingers under the chain just as the conductor began rising again. This motion caused the chain to tighten, trapping the injured person's left hand and amputating the tips of two fingers (middle and ring finger between fingernail and first knuckle). The incident occurred because the 'all stop' call was not confirmed by the casing jack operator, who was simultaneously checking the conductor's weight. The injured person mistook the brief pause for a confirmed stop and proceeded with chain adjustment.
recommendations: Develop and implement comprehensive risk assessment for marine growth removal activities
Implement written management of change procedures for equipment and method changes
Improve radio communication protocols to ensure confirmation of 'all stop' commands
Evaluate alternative marine growth removal methods that minimize worker proximity to moving equipment
Submit amended APM to BSEE/BOEM when deviating from approved methods
Ensure JSAs and work permits adequately address specific task hazards
Implement positive communication confirmation system for critical operations

hazards.name: Moving conductor under tension with chains
Heavy equipment operation in confined space

threats.name: Unconfirmed 'all stop' command during chain adjustment
Worker hand placement near moving chain and conductor
Inadequate risk assessment of marine growth removal methods
Failure to implement management of change procedures
Deviation from approved APM without notification

controls.name: Radio communication system for 'all stop' commands
controls.barrier_role: Prevent unauthorized movement during maintenance
controls.lod_basis: Operational control to prevent hazardous movement

supporting_text: A call for an 'all stop' came over the radio from the trainee on the +44 level, but no one confirmed it
According to Chevron's procedures, any station can request an 'all stop,' and the Weatherford Lead will acknowledge the 'all stop' and select a control to stop the casing jack
The Weatherford Lead reported in his witness statement that the only 'all stop' he heard was from the trainee who had reported that there had been an injury

controls.name: Weatherford Lead confirmation of 'all stop' before stopping casing jack
controls.barrier_role: Ensure safe work authorization before maintenance
controls.lod_basis: Operational control requiring positive confirmation

supporting_text: Rep 1 also confirmed that he himself did hear over the radio the 'all stop' intended for the chain adjustment, but did not hear the Weatherford Lead confirm it
Against Chevron's operating procedures, IP used this pause to adjust the chain without getting 'all stop' confirmation

controls.barrier_role: Personal verification before entering hazard zone
controls.lod_basis: Individual worker safety check

supporting_text: IP used this stop to adjust the chain, neither getting 'all stop' confirmation nor realizing the conductor would start rising again after the weight check
seeing movement stop, IP placed his left hand fingers under the chain just as the conductor began rising again

controls.name: Job Safety Analysis (JSA) for marine growth removal
controls.barrier_role: Identify and control hazards before work begins
controls.lod_basis: Pre-job hazard identification and control

supporting_text: BSEE reviewed the JSAs and work permits for the task of marine growth removal and determined that the JSAs cautioned workers, including IP, about hand placement and good communication prior to the incident

BSEE also found that Chevron's reliance on the JSAs and work permits for conductor removal operations was insufficient to identify and evaluate risks and ensure that safeguards were in place for the specific activity of marine growth removal

controls.name: Management of Change (MOC) procedures for equipment/method changes
controls.barrier_role: Ensure changes are properly assessed and controlled
controls.lod_basis: Management system oversight of operational changes

supporting_text: Chevron did not produce any MOC records, stating that it did not perform a comprehensive risk analysis of changing from one MGRS method to another
BSEE concluded that Chevron switched through three different MGRS methods without developing and implementing written MOC procedures, as required by 30 CFR § 250.1912(a)(2)
Chevron identified two root causes (inadequate verbal communication and no risk assessment) and two contributing factors (MOC inadequate for design change and inadequate written communication)

controls.name: Comprehensive risk assessment for marine growth removal methods
controls.barrier_role: Identify hazards and implement mitigation measures
controls.lod_basis: Engineering and management review of work methods

supporting_text: Chevron's report acknowledges that one of the root causes of the incident was the lack of a risk assessment of the marine growth removal activity
BSEE's investigation found that Chevron did not properly or thoroughly analyze the risks posed by any of the MGRS methods it had used
Nor did Chevron conduct a risk or hazards analysis on the chain or chain-link fence fabric MGRS methods prior to their use

controls.name: APM approval and notification for method changes
controls.barrier_role: Regulatory oversight of operational changes
controls.lod_basis: External regulatory review and approval

supporting_text: At no time prior to or during conductor removal operations did Chevron submit to BOEM or BSEE an amended APM with documentation stating that it was going to use, or was considering using, MGRS methods other than the diver method
Furthermore, Chevron deviated from its approved APM and failed to provide any notification to BSEE of the amended course of action
At no time does Chevron indicate any alternative method to be considered for the removal of the marine growth from the conductors

controls.name: Safety briefing and pass-over information

controls.lod_basis: Operational communication and awareness

supporting_text: At 18:00, the night shift conductor removal crew held a safety meeting and received pass-over information from the day shift
During the meeting, personnel discussed that a collar was just below the +44 platform level, and all involved will need to be ready for an 'all stop' to make adjustments

controls.lod_basis: Pre-operational verification

supporting_text: Around 18:15, crewmembers inspected their workstation and equipment

controls.barrier_role: Ensure competent personnel perform critical tasks
controls.lod_basis: Competency assurance through supervision

supporting_text: The CEC contractor at that station called out over the radio that he was not ready. The CEC contractor was a trainee working on the MGRS for the first time and was waiting for the experienced worker (IP) to show up

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Ship Shoal 224 D Platform Hand Injury

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Ship Shoal Area Block 224

event.incident_type: Personnel Injury - Hand Caught in Crane Equipment
actions_taken: IP evacuated for medical treatment
All operations shut down for investigation
Stand-down held focusing on line of fire and hand placement during crane operations
Additional wire rope slings added to rigging to prevent crane block from being lowered through deck opening
Personnel reminded to keep radio communications clear and use buddy system
event.summary: On July 20, 2024, at approximately 2200 hours, a rigger suffered lacerations to his ring finger and partial amputation of his pinky finger when his right hand was caught between the crane cable and crane block sheave while guiding a casing cutter tool through deck openings during abandonment operations at Ship Shoal 224 D platform. The injured person was using his hands to guide the crane block instead of push poles as required by company policy. The incident occurred during a blind lift operation where the crane operator could not see the load due to the lift boat being jacked up above the platform deck level.
key_phrases: hand caught between crane cable and crane block sheave

consequences.name: Personnel injury - hand laceration and partial amputation

supporting_text: The operator did not enforce its Safe Operating Practices (TSOP-PCD-50) Material Handling and the IP did not follow this policy.
The operator's Material Handling policy specifies using push poles to guide suspended loads.
IP used his hands to guide the load instead of using push poles.

controls.name: Job Safety Analysis (JSA) for Crane Operations
controls.barrier_role: Identify and communicate hazards before work begins
controls.lod_basis: Pre-job hazard identification and planning

supporting_text: JSA's were completed for Abrasive Cutting Operations, Crane Ops for night shift 1800-0600, General Work on Deck, and Removing Conductors.
Although blind lifts and hand placement was discussed in the pre-tour meeting, these hazards were not identified in any JSA used that night.
The JSA's were inadequate because they did not identify the hazard of blind lifts or the pinch point between the crane's cable and sheave.

controls.name: Stop Work Authority (SWA)
controls.barrier_role: Empower workers to stop unsafe work
controls.lod_basis: Real-time intervention to prevent unsafe conditions

supporting_text: Stop Work Authority (SWA) was not used when the IP started guiding the load with his hands instead of a push pole.
SWA was used, but only after the IP's hand was caught between the crane's cable and sheave.

controls.name: Radio Communication for Blind Lifts
controls.barrier_role: Enable coordination during operations with limited visibility
controls.lod_basis: Communication control for coordinated operations

supporting_text: All lifts were blind lifts due to the lift boat being jacked-up to the top of its legs. The top deck of the platform was higher than the crane cab on the lift boat's crane, therefore all lifts required the use of radios.
Once the IP realized his fingers were caught in the sheave and cable of the crane, he called for the crane to stop.
When he noticed the IP's hand caught in the sheave, he ran over to another team member with a radio and called for an all stop.

controls.lod_basis: Competency assurance through training and certification

supporting_text: It was also noted that the IP is a certified rigger.
Human error performance - IP was not aware of the pinch between the crane's cable and sheave.

controls.name: Buddy System
controls.barrier_role: Provide peer observation and intervention
controls.lod_basis: Peer monitoring for unsafe acts

supporting_text: Personnel were reminded to keep radio communications clear and to use the buddy system.
The IP and R1 were posted in these positions to keep the crane cable, crane block, wire rope slings and umbilical from rubbing on the grating and I-beams on each deck.

controls.name: Emergency Response - Crane Stop and Rescue
controls.barrier_role: Minimize injury severity through rapid response
controls.lod_basis: Emergency response to limit consequences

supporting_text: Once the IP realized his fingers were caught in the sheave and cable of the crane, he called for the crane to stop.

Another member of the casing cutting team heard the IP yell out in pain. When he noticed the IP's hand caught in the sheave, he ran over to another team member with a radio and called for an all stop.
He then instructed the crane operator (CO) to lower the block until the IP's hand was free from the block.

controls.name: Medical Evacuation Capability
controls.barrier_role: Provide timely medical treatment to minimize injury impact
controls.lod_basis: Emergency medical response capability

supporting_text: The IP was taken to the galley for evaluation.

controls.lod_basis: Organizational learning and corrective action

supporting_text: All operations were shut down for investigation and a stand-down was held.
The focus of the stand-down was line of fire and hand placement during crane operations.
Additional wire rope slings were added to the rigging to prevent the crane block from having to be lowered through the opening in the deck.

source.title: Fire at High Island 547 B Platform - Glycol Dehydration Unit

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - High Island Area Block 547

actions_taken: Platform emergency shut down device activated
Fire extinguished using two 150 pound and two 30-pound fire extinguishers
Fire extinguished in ten minutes
Glycol Reboiler Dehydration unit removed and transported to Universal Equipment Company for inspection
Root cause analysis conducted with third-party consultant GIR Solutions
event.summary: On January 5, 2023, at 1730 hours, a fire occurred at High Island 547 B platform involving the Glycol Reboiler Dehydration system. The still column vent pipe became plugged, resulting in pressure build up until it ruptured. The rupture caused glycol to spray which contacted the reboiler and exhaust stack (operating at 750-800°F), igniting the glycol mixture. Platform operators activated emergency shutdown and extinguished the fire in ten minutes using fire extinguishers. No injuries or pollution occurred. Fire damage was limited to the Glycol Reboiler and Dehydration unit, totaling over $100,000.
recommendations: Develop a servicing plan to inspect the Still Column Vent piping
Implement a still column replacement campaign to coincide with the 5-year fire tube inspection requirement
Perform a condition assessment of all still columns across the gulf by the end of 1st quarter FY 23

glycol to spray which contacted the reboiler and exhaust stack

source.title: Fire Incident - Universal Power Supply Failure at Perdido Spar

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Alaminos Canyon Block 857

event.summary: On January 3, 2023, at 2210 hours, a DC capacitor on Universal Power Supply UPS-7560 failed at the Perdido Spar platform, causing smoke release, arcing/sparking, and activation of smoke detectors. The automated safety system shut-in the facility and caused full power loss. The Fire Team responded but found no visible fire. The Electrical Team isolated power feeds and identified the failed inverter through troubleshooting. The UPS was locked out and bypassed, with a spare circuit providing power. Estimated repair cost is $56,830 with 7-9 weeks lead time for parts. No injuries or pollution occurred.
recommendations: Implement Preventative Maintenance Plan (PMI) to replace all fans, AC and DC capacitors on like units

source.title: Dropped Object Incident - Valaris DS-18

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Walker Ridge Block 758

actions_taken: Safety Standdown implemented

event.summary: On March 21, 2023, at 02:30 hours, a 25-pound riser bolt insert dislodged from a riser flange and fell approximately 75 feet to the rig floor on the drillship Valaris DS-18. The insert passed between two Floorhands and struck an aluminum stairway, damaging two steps. The drill crew was running marine riser joint #36 using the Top Drive when the incident occurred. Investigation revealed that the riser retainer pin was either never installed or fell out during transport, and the required retention cable (sling) was not installed as specified in Step 6, Item 'd' of the WIMS. Personnel failed to stop work immediately after the incident and continued making up riser bolts for several minutes before reporting.
recommendations: Develop checklist with all pertinent safety steps for running riser to be attached to WIMS
Break down long WIMS or repetitive operations into stages
Designate second crew member to verify WIMS steps are being followed
OIM to develop Stop Work Authority Drill program to increase personnel comfort level in stopping jobs when needed

threats.name: Inadequate securing of riser bolt inserts
Failure to install retention devices (retainer pin and sling)
Incomplete review and communication of WIMS procedures

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Hand Injury During Wireline Operations

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Green Canyon Block 389

actions_taken: Job stopped and worksite secured
IP evaluated by rig medic
IP evacuated to onshore facility
IP received 14 stitches and treatment for broken finger
IP released to light duty on 4/22/24
IP released to full duty on 5/22/24
event.summary: On April 22, 2024, a hand injury occurred on the drillship Noble Stanley Lafosse during wireline completion operations at Green Canyon Block 389. The injured person (IP) was assisting the wireline helper disconnect wireline tools when his right hand was caught between the upper C-plate with tools weighing 175 lbs and lower C-plate. The helper had raised the tool string approximately 4 inches above the bottom C-plate. The IP placed his right hand under the upper C-plate to stabilize the tool string. When the helper released the tools, they fell 4 inches, smashing the IP's right hand between the C-plates, causing lacerations to the right hand ring and middle fingertips and a broken finger tip. The IP required evacuation and 14 stitches. Investigation revealed the helper lacked deepwater experience, the IP was not properly trained on wireline tools, the JSEA was inadequate, communication was poor, and Stop Work Authority was not used.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Fall Through Open Hole on Drillship

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Walker Ridge Block 51

actions_taken: Job was stopped immediately

event.summary: On March 28, 2024, the Transocean Subsea Superintendent fell approximately nine feet through an open hole on a BOP work platform on the drillship Transocean Deepwater Atlas. The hatch cover had been removed after its hinge separated, creating a dropped object hazard, but no barrier was installed and the open hole was not communicated to the work team. The IP was wearing a safety harness but was not tied off. He injured his knee and shin and was evacuated for medical treatment. The remote control box he was carrying fell an additional 40 feet. Investigation found failures in communication, hazard identification, and implementation of corrective actions.

source.title: Structural Damage - Crane Incident at Green Canyon Block 52 Platform A

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Green Canyon Block 52

actions_taken: Operation stopped when stinger latched to boom lace observed
PIC notified of the situation
Boom lowered without lowering main block simultaneously
Visual inspection conducted after stinger pulled free
Crane continued in operation until June 6, 2024
BSEE inspectors took crane out of service on June 6, 2024
Independent crane inspector derated crane lifting capacity to 50% on June 10, 2024
Crane boom tip replaced at cost of $70,000
Crane load tested and returned to service on June 16, 2024
event.summary: On May 31, 2024, during boat offloading/backloading operations at Green Canyon Block 52 Platform A, a stinger attached to the crane's main block latched onto a lace of the crane boom. When the PIC instructed the crane operator to lower the boom without simultaneously lowering the main block (ignoring CO-2's warning), the stinger pulled free and broke a weld on the boom lace. Despite discovering the damage the next day during pre-use inspection, the PIC instructed crew to continue using the damaged crane. The crane remained in operation from May 31 until BSEE inspectors took it out of service on June 6, 2024. BSEE was not immediately notified of the incident as required.

failed to identify hazard of leaving stinger on big block
JSA did not cover possibility of stinger hanging up on boom

event.summary: On October 12, 2024, a Derrickman (IP) was injured onboard the Noble Valiant drilling rig during tripping operations. The IP positioned himself on the upper fingerboards, outside the designated safe observation area, without a working-at-heights permit to tie up a malfunctioning fingerboard latch. While working on the latch for approximately 10 minutes, the Pipe Racking System (PRS), operating in automatic mode, extended to retrieve a stand of pipe. The IP was caught and pinned between the PRS arm and the pipe stand. Coworkers heard his calls for help, the AD engaged the emergency stop, and the IP was freed and evacuated for medical treatment. The incident resulted from policy violations and lack of situational awareness by multiple parties.
recommendations: The Lake Jackson District has no recommendations

event.summary: On 27 September 2024, a Deckhand on the M/V Harvey Freedom support vessel injured his leg during equipment back-loading operations from the Noble Valiant drillship. While attempting to steady a 50-foot basket with a tagline as it was being landed, the support vessel rolled causing the IP to lose footing and injure his left leg. The IP was evacuated to the drillship, then to shore, required surgery, and resulted in more than 3-days lost time.

event.top_event: Loss of Containment - Personnel in Line of Fire

event.summary: On December 8, 2023, at approximately 08:30 am, a Floorhand (IP) sustained a lost time injury when contacted by the Top Drive System (TDS) while positioned on the port pipe racker upper access platform approximately 80 feet above the drill floor on the Noble Globetrotter II drilling rig. The IP had moved to the platform to troubleshoot a 'slack rope detected' alarm without notifying the Driller. As the Driller lowered the TDS during tripping operations, the lower port TDS roller assembly contacted the IP, folding his upper torso around the outside handrail. The IP sustained a punctured lung, fractured ribs, and a fractured scapula. The incident resulted from inadequate communication, failure to identify the moving equipment hazard in the JSA, lack of warning signage, and absence of engineered barriers despite only 3 inches clearance between the TDS and platform handrail.

source.title: Arc Flash Fire - Perdido SPAR - SCR Failure

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Alaminos Canyon Block 857

event.summary: On October 3, 2024, at approximately 9:00 am, an arc flash fire occurred on Shell's Perdido SPAR when a Silicon Controlled Rectifier (SCR) failed in the SCR house. During wireline logging operations, the cement pump was being used to pump base oil into well GA017 for hydrate mitigation when the cement unit's electronic panel lost power. When the Tool Pusher and Rig Electrician entered the SCR room to investigate, they heard a loud popping sound and observed smoke. Evidence of arcing between DC buss bars, arcing on circuit breaker heat sinks, and a failed buss insulator in SCR cabinet #1 was identified. The fire and gas alarm system did not detect the fire; it was only identified when personnel entered the SCR house. The well was secured and SCR cabinet #1 was isolated for repair.

source.title: Unauthorized Release of Synthetic Based Mud - Shell Perdido Spar

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Alaminos Canyon Block 857

event.incident_type: Unauthorized discharge of drilling fluid to sea
actions_taken: Well was shut-in and circulated out through gas buster

BSEE investigation conducted on 9/5/2023
event.summary: On September 4, 2023, approximately 24 barrels of Synthetic Based Mud (SBM) were discharged into the Gulf of Mexico from the H&P 205 drilling rig on Shell's Perdido Spar. The crew was circulating a clean out run and had transferred 117 bbls of SBM to processing pits to remove entrained gas. Seven minutes after the transfer pump was turned off, the degasser tank volume began decreasing. Investigation revealed that both the knife valve on the degasser tank discharge line and the butterfly valve (master dump valve) had leaked due to obstructions - cuttings in the knife valve and a piece of rubber in the butterfly valve - preventing proper sealing. The crew had visually verified valve positions per procedure but did not functionally test the valves prior to transfer. The valves had not been operated since April 2023.
recommendations: Crews will fill processing pits with sea water to check for any leaks through containment valves prior to future operations
key_phrases: no skillet on processing pit master dump valve

event.summary: On June 21, 2023, at 0930 hours, a Variable Frequency Device A (VFD-A) failed at the Perdido Spar platform. The B-phase reactor of the VFD-A failed to ground, releasing smoke that activated smoke detectors in the Subsea Motor Control Center room. This triggered an automated facility shut-in and personnel muster. The Fire Team responded but found no active fire, only smoke. Cabinet A reached 350°F and was isolated from service. Estimated damage cost was $65,000. No injuries or pollution occurred.
recommendations: Siemens to investigate why the reactor thermal switch did not trip the drive on over temperature

event.summary: On 19 November 2022 at approximately 0430 hours, motor vessel Jacob Gerald allided into West Delta 31 Platform E-DRL while transporting personnel. The captain dozed off before impact. The vessel was traveling at cruising speed of 8 knots when the captain fell asleep. A production operator aboard the vessel reported back soreness and was transported to an onshore medical facility, later released to full duty (first aid case). The allision caused damage to several structural members. The platform was shut in and the damaged area barricaded. Engineering analysis determined the platform was safe to man with wave heights below 20 feet. Total repair costs remain unknown but not expected to exceed $25K.

source.title: U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board Urgent Recommendations - ConAgra Slim Jim Facility Explosion

context.region: Garner, North Carolina, United States

actions_taken: ConAgra established procedure requiring direct venting of purged gases outdoors via hose or piping
ConAgra established procedure requiring exclusion of personnel and ignition sources from vicinity of vent
ConAgra established procedure requiring continuous air monitoring using combustible gas detectors
ConAgra established procedure requiring evacuation of nonessential personnel from facility
North Carolina Building Code Council adopted emergency changes to state code to prohibit indoor venting during fuel gas purging operations
event.summary: On June 9, 2009, a catastrophic natural gas explosion occurred at the ConAgra Slim Jim production facility in Garner, North Carolina, resulting in 4 deaths, 3 critical burn injuries, 1 amputation, and 67 total hospitalizations. The explosion occurred during installation and commissioning of a new 5-million BTU per hour gas-fired industrial water heater. Over a two-and-a-half hour period, natural gas was purged from new piping into an interior utility room rather than vented outdoors. Personnel relied on sense of smell rather than combustible gas detectors to monitor gas concentration. The gas accumulated to explosive levels and ignited, causing serious structural damage including 37% roof collapse. The explosion also damaged ammonia refrigeration system piping, releasing approximately 18,000 pounds of toxic anhydrous ammonia to the environment, contaminating local surface waters and causing a fish kill. Over 200 nonessential personnel were present in the facility during the purging activity.
recommendations: Enact Tentative Interim Amendment and permanent changes to National Fuel Gas Code requiring purged fuel gases be directly vented to safe location outdoors away from personnel and ignition sources

If indoor venting necessary, require approval by authority having jurisdiction of documented risk evaluation and hazard control plan including evacuation of nonessential personnel, adequate ventilation, and control of ignition sources
Require combustible gas detectors to continuously monitor gas concentration at appropriate locations where purged gases are released
Require personnel training about odor fade and odor fatigue and warn against relying on odor alone for detecting fuel gas releases
Incorporate revised gas purging provisions into International Fuel Gas Code

hazards.name: Toxic anhydrous ammonia under pressure in refrigeration system

threats.name: Accumulation of natural gas to explosive concentration during indoor purging
Ignition of flammable gas-air mixture by unclassified electrical equipment
Inadequate ventilation during gas purging operations
Failure to detect flammable gas concentration due to odor fade
Damage to ammonia refrigeration piping from explosion overpressure

consequences.name: Severe injuries - 3 critical burn injuries, 1 amputation, 67 total hospitalizations
Structural collapse - 37% roof collapse, 60% roof damaged or unstable
Secondary toxic release - 18,000 pounds anhydrous ammonia released to environment
Environmental damage - surface water contamination and fish kill
Economic harm - plant operations suspended, several hundred employees laid off
Emergency responder injuries - 3 firefighters hospitalized for ammonia exposure

source.title: Crane Incident - Nansen Spar Platform

context.region: Gulf of America, East Breaks Block 602

actions_taken: All stop declared

event.summary: On 21-May-2025 at approximately 1:45 p.m., a crane incident occurred on the Nansen Spar platform. Contract scaffold builders attached multiple 1/4-ton lever hoists to the crane boom for scaffolding stabilization without notifying the Lifting Authority. When the crane operator lifted the boom out of its rest after lunch break without conducting a pre-use inspection, one lever hoist broke and fell approximately 30 feet to the flare boom mezzanine deck. No injuries occurred. The incident resulted from communication failures, inadequate supervision, and simultaneous operations in a confined area.
recommendations: Verification of Temporary Anchor Points: The Lifting Authority will verify all temporary anchor points used for rigging prior to lifting operations
Control of Work Update: The control of work procedures will be updated for the lifting and rigging section, requiring the Lifting Authority to sign off on the approval of anchor points
Development of HSE Alert: An HSE alert will be developed to outline the failures that contributed to the incident, along with the corrective actions taken
Policy Update for Rigging and Lifting: The rigging and lifting policy will be updated to mandate inspections of the crane whenever the boom is placed into the boom rest

source.title: Structural Damage - Zinc Bromide Brine Release at East Cameron Block 71

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - East Cameron Block 71

actions_taken: Casing valve closed to stop discharge
NRC Report #1368219 submitted
BSEE notified via email
Initial investigation conducted May 26, 2023
Follow-up investigation conducted June 14, 2023
Electronic Drilling Recorder data reviewed
event.summary: On May 25, 2023, at 1:15am, approximately 79 barrels of zinc bromide brine was inadvertently discharged from a wellhead casing valve at Well Number C007 on Platform C at East Cameron Block 71. During BOP testing operations, a Floorhand was assigned to close a 1 13/16-inch 10M gate valve on the wellhead casing. The Floorhand believed the valve was closed but it was not fully closed. When zinc bromide brine was pumped to refill the production casing and BOP, the partially open valve allowed fluid to discharge into the Gulf of Mexico. The Floorhand noticed slower than normal returns and was sent to recheck the valve, where he fully closed it and stopped the flow. Investigation using Pit Volume Totalizer data determined the actual release was 79 barrels, significantly more than the initially reported 28 barrels.

event.summary: On 21 September 2023 at approximately 0130 hours, a night shift Supervisor sustained a compound fracture with exposed bone on his lower left shin when an unsecured 8000-pound wellhead rolled onto his leg after he sat on it and stood up. The wellhead had been removed from Well #13 during day shift operations and laid on its side on the deck of the Lift Boat Man-O-War without proper securing. Personnel had attempted to check stability by hand before removing rigging, but this was insufficient. The wellhead was in an unstable position and may have shifted due to lift boat movements from weather and crane activity. The injured party was evacuated by medevac helicopter for medical treatment, resulting in days away from work.
recommendations: Keep scrap basket onboard to contain and secure wellheads after removal
Ensure adequate hazard analysis and written job procedures for wellhead removal operations
Provide adequate tools and equipment for securing loads on deck
Improve JSA process to identify job steps, hazards, and mitigation measures

source.title: Crane Auxiliary Jib Detachment - Eugene Island 252 I Facility

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Eugene Island Block 252

event.top_event: Structural Damage - Crane Auxiliary Jib Detachment
actions_taken: Crane boom placed over heliport to prevent auxiliary jib from falling to deck

event.summary: On August 20, 2023, at approximately 1000 hours, the auxiliary jib on the platform crane detached while attempting to relocate a construction supply box weighing 3,886 lbs. The crane operator failed to center the auxiliary line over the construction supply box, causing it to become lodged on a capping beam. Continued lifting created a side loading effect that caused the boom to twist, shearing the auxiliary jib bolts and causing the jib to detach. The auxiliary jib became entangled in hydraulic lines, preventing it from falling to the deck. The rigger failed to communicate the all stop signal. No injuries occurred. Repairs totaled $80,000.
recommendations: Crane operator to attend refresher training through different training program
Arena to improve internal process for selection and assignment of crane operators on facilities

event.summary: On October 3, 2025, at approximately 1230 hours, a contract fitter sustained a severe injury to his right leg during decommissioning operations on the White Fleet Operating OCS-G00985 Eugene Island 259 C Facility. While attempting to install stabilizing brackets to support piping during platform removal operations, a section of 8-inch pipe was cut approximately 20 feet away from the CF. Once the section was cut, the remaining pipe shifted and slid towards the CF, pinning his right leg between a flange on the cut pipe and the piping the CF's leg was draped across. The CF suffered multiple fractures of the right femur. The incident was caused by inadequate job instructions and failure to communicate crew locations, and inadequate hazard analysis that failed to address potential pipe movement due to stored energy.
recommendations: Review locations of where crews will be located during decommissioning operations in pre-job safety meetings
Ensure JSA addresses hazards of potential pipe movement due to stored energy
Ensure piping being cut is secured to prevent shifting once cut is made

event.summary: On October 13, 2023, at approximately 1745 hours, a crane mechanic fell approximately 96 ft from the gantry of a crane into the water at Cox Operating's Eugene Island 259 C Facility. While attempting to replace the auxiliary winch, the crane mechanic positioned himself over the handrail without wearing a safety harness or life vest to remove a brace blocking the winch installation. When the second bolt broke, the brace detached and contacted the crane mechanic, causing him to fall over the handrails. He suffered a fractured rib, dislocated shoulder, and internal bleeding.

event.summary: On 17 March 2025 at 2140 hours, during well abandonment operations at Eugene Island Block 307A, a single joint of 3.5-inch pipe fell approximately 40 feet to the deck. The incident occurred when a crane operator, without clear line of sight, lowered the pipe onto a Self-Retracting Lifeline (SRL) Arm in an elevated hydraulic jack basket. When the floor hand pushed the pipe off the SRL arm, the impact caused worn elevator doors to open, releasing the pipe. Two workers in the area moved out of the way before the pipe struck a hydraulic hose and fire extinguisher handle. No injuries or pollution occurred; damages totaled $4,000.

source.title: Structural Damage - High Pressure Hose Rupture

context.region: Gulf of America - Garden Banks Block 215

actions_taken: Three injured personnel evaluated by Rig Medic
Two personnel evacuated for further medical evaluation on 17 July 2025
Third personnel evacuated for further medical evaluation on 18 July 2025

BSEE conducted onsite investigation on 21 July 2025
event.summary: On 17 July 2025 at 0752 hours, during workover operations at Garden Banks Block 215, a 0.375-inch high-pressure hose ruptured while blowing down a coil tubing reel with nitrogen. The ruptured hose struck a Noble Assistant Driller on his left arm and an Oil States employee on the left side of his face. A Schlumberger Operator injured his knee while moving to avoid being struck. All three injuries were classified as First Aid Only. Laboratory analysis determined the hose failed due to chlorides corrosion coupled with rapid oxidation of wire reinforcement strands. The 3000 psi rated hose had only been in use for approximately 6 months and was pressurized to 2400 psi when it ruptured. Investigation found no safety restraints were installed on the manifold as recommended in Oil States Standard Operating Procedure, and there was no established hose inspection procedure or preventative maintenance program in place.

Third employee moved to safe distance on walkway

event.summary: On 16 July 2025 at 1810 hours, an external walkway platform on the third floor of a Temporary Living Quarters (TLQ) at Devils Tower SPAR platform unexpectedly detached from the TLQ structure by 12-18 inches while three Nabors employees were standing on it. The walkway remained held by stanchions and stairway connections. Investigation revealed inadequate welded tabs that lacked sufficient surface area for long-term support, combined with 23 years of marine corrosion and fatigue. The TLQ was originally designed as temporary housing in 2002 but remained in service. Visual-only inspections failed to detect weld deterioration. No injuries or dropped objects occurred due to immediate securing actions.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends Office of Incident Investigations consider issuing a Safety Alert
Eni to ensure future design and construction of temporary structures account for potential long-term use
Eni to incorporate dedicated inspections and protocols for TLQs focusing on marine corrosion, fatigue and weld conditions
Eni created specific annual inspection requirements for TLQ landings and tab welds in CMMS
key_phrases: deteriorated condition of the welded tabs

hazards.name: Structural failure energy from inadequate support

threats.name: Inadequate weld design for long-term use
Marine corrosion and material fatigue
Lack of structural cross bracing
Temporary structure used beyond design life

consequences.name: Personnel injury from fall or structural collapse

The most recent Level 1 survey that was conducted in May 2024 did not indicate any discrepancies in the walkways or structures for the TLQ. This was most likely due to only visual inspections having been performed

source.title: Crane Lifting Pin Failure Incident - Vermilion Block 38M

context.region: Gulf of America, Vermilion Block 38, Lease 00204

actions_taken: Medic called immediately to scene
IP placed in personnel basket and lifted to liftboat

event.summary: On July 12, 2025, at approximately 3:30 p.m., a casing lifting pin failed during well abandonment operations on the VR-38M platform. The 2-inch diameter lifting pin bent into a U-shape under excessive load and struck a Supreme Services employee in the face, causing severe injuries including subdural hematoma, skull fracture, and facial bone fractures. The incident occurred when the crane operator attempted to lift stuck 7-inch casing using the main hoist. Investigation revealed the casing became stuck because a spool riser with 11.00-inch inside diameter was installed over a seal ring with 11.44-inch outside diameter. The lifting pin failed at an estimated load exceeding 102,000 pounds, well above its 60,000-pound safe working load limit. Contributing factors included improper sling installation with D-rings not adjacent to the casing, exceeding the approved lift plan's maximum weight capacity of 24,255 pounds, and failure to call an all-stop when the casing became stuck.
recommendations: BSEE Lake Charles District recommends Office of Incident Investigations issue a Safety Alert/Bulletin regarding this incident

hazards.name: Mechanical Energy from Crane Lifting Operations

threats.name: Dimensional incompatibility between spool riser and seal ring
Exceeding safe working load limit of lifting equipment
Improper rigging installation (D-rings not adjacent to casing)
Failure to stop operations when casing became stuck
Use of incorrect hoist (main vs auxiliary) without plan revision

consequences.name: Personnel injury - severe facial and skull trauma
Equipment damage - crane main hoist wire rope
Equipment damage - casing lifting pin destroyed

source.title: Nitrogen Bottle Explosion - BW Pioneer FPSO

context.region: Gulf of America, Walker Ridge Area Block 249

actions_taken: IP immediately shut valve to jet fuel pump

event.summary: On April 28, 2025, a nitrogen bottle exploded on the BW Pioneer FPSO during refilling operations. The bottle, rated for 2,400 psi, was mistakenly filled to over 5,000 psi because it was misidentified as a 6,000 psi bottle. The incorrect 9,000 psi relief valve installed during maintenance in December 2023 failed to prevent overpressurization. The explosion caused structural damage to the bottle rack, damaged nearby equipment including a diesel tank, and injured a crane operator with shrapnel, causing hearing impairment and minor bruises.
recommendations: Install correct pressure relief valves rated for cylinder design pressure
Develop formal written procedures for nitrogen bottle filling operations
Implement proper training program on cylinder identification and pressure ratings
Clearly identify and segregate bottles by pressure rating
Update JSA to specify target pressure and identify overpressurization hazards
Establish routine inspection and maintenance program for pressure vessels

threats.name: Overpressurization of nitrogen bottle beyond design capacity
Incorrect pressure relief device installed
Misidentification of bottle pressure rating

Had the cylinders been fitted with the correct relief valve, the over-pressurization could have been avoided

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Structural Damage/Lost Time Injury

event.summary: On February 7, 2024, at approximately 09:30 am, a Danos contractor sustained a lost time injury (broken leg and ankle) when an inadequately built scaffolding ladder shifted while he was climbing it on the third rung. The ladder had been placed out of service on January 1, 2024, when the Self-Retracting Lanyard and scaffold tag were removed, but no visual identifiers marked it as OOS. The ladder had only two attachment points and was improperly constructed. The injured person jumped to the deck when the ladder shifted, sustaining injuries to both lower legs. Multiple systemic failures contributed including inadequate communication between operators and contractors, lack of bridging documents, no operator involvement in JSA processes, improper equipment inspection and maintenance, and inadequate fall protection equipment.
recommendations: All operators review or revisit Safety Alert No. 469 (BSEE Identifies Medical Evacuation and Emergency Hazards During Risk-Based Inspections)
key_phrases: inadequate communication between operator and platform personnel/contractors

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Hand Injury During AHU Belt Inspection

context.region: Gulf of America - Garden Banks Block 259

actions_taken: Injured worker reported to Rig Medic for treatment
Worker evacuated by medevac helicopter on 3 June 2025 to East Jefferson Hospital
Minor surgery performed to close wound
Worker released to work with light duty restrictions
BSEE conducted onsite Incident Follow-up Investigation on 4 June 2025
G-110 (C) Incident of Noncompliance (INC) issued to Hess Corporation
event.summary: On 02 June 2025, a Transocean Second Engineer sustained a hand injury during drilling operations at Garden Banks Block 259. While checking the tension on an air handling unit (AHU) belt in the Mud Module Electrical Room, he placed his left hand on a moving belt without proper lockout/tagout isolation. His hand was drawn between the belt and pulley, resulting in partial amputation of the left hand middle and ring fingertips. The engineer had shut off power but did not perform full energy isolation, worked without supervision, and did not communicate his task change to his supervisor. He was evacuated and treated for amputation of distal ends of middle and ring fingers with open non-displaced fractures.
recommendations: Hess must submit a letter of explanation within 14 days to the Lafayette District Well Operations Section Chief on the Incident of Non-Compliance along with plans to prevent future incidents of this nature

source.title: Gas Release Incident - Valaris DS-16 - Garden Banks 668

context.region: Gulf of America - Garden Banks Block 668

actions_taken: Personnel evacuated shaker house
Abandonment crew shut down mud pumps
Abandonment crew closed the choke
Quick Response Team dispatched

All clear announced after gas levels returned to zero
Operations continued after incident discussion
event.summary: On 15 November 2024 at 0837 hours, a gas release occurred in the shaker house onboard the Valaris DS-16 drillship during well abandonment operations at Garden Banks 668. While attempting to bullhead well SS011, a hydrate plug formed in the production tubing. The crew displaced the landing string and kill line with nitrogen to dissipate the hydrate, then attempted to displace back to 12.2 ppg CaBr2. During this displacement, the liquid leg of the mud gas separator was compromised, allowing hydrocarbon gas to bypass the separator and enter the shaker house, triggering a hydrocarbon alarm and requiring full crew muster. Gas levels returned to zero and operations resumed without further issues.
recommendations: Conduct safety meetings with all four crews expressing the importance of circulating fluids/gases from well and how it could impact the mud gas separator liquid leg
Recognize that liquid leg can be impacted differently with mud, brine, and nitrogen in the circulating system

threats.name: Hydrate plug formation in production tubing
Loss of mud gas separator liquid leg during nitrogen circulation
Improper control of returns through choke and mud gas separator

consequences.name: Hydrocarbon gas release to shaker house atmosphere

event.summary: On 21 April 2023 at 0938 hours, the TO Discoverer Inspiration drillship experienced an intense frontal passage with 67 knot winds during well abandonment operations. The drillship began drifting off location, requiring activation of the Emergency Disconnect System (EDS). This resulted in discharge of 513 barrels of calcium bromide into Gulf of Mexico waters. Two thrusters (#4 and #6) were operating at reduced power during the event for unknown reasons. No injuries, muster, or equipment damage occurred. The EDS performed as intended.

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Shoulder Injury During Coil Tubing Operations

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Garden Banks Block 506

actions_taken: IP evacuated via medevac helicopter at 1010 hours
BSEE conducted onsite investigation on 20 March 2024
IP diagnosed with dislocated shoulder and torn labrum

G-110 Incident of Non-Compliance issued to Talos ERT LLC on 2 April 2024
event.summary: On 20 March 2024 at approximately 0705 hours, a Schlumberger Pump Operator sustained a left shoulder injury on the Helix Q-4000 semisubmersible vessel during well workover operations. The injured party attempted to jump across a four-foot gap with a one-foot eight-inch rise in elevation from the Coil Tubing Control Cabin to the Coil Tubing Reel Platform to install a Universal Tubing Length Monitor. During the transition, the IP lost his footing and started to fall. He grabbed the Coil Tubing Cabin crash frame with his left hand, injuring his left shoulder. The IP was wearing fall protection harness with self-retracting lanyard. Investigation determined the IP failed to follow the Job Safety Analysis which required use of a ladder for access.
recommendations: Talos ERT LLC must provide a letter of explanation within 14 days to the Lafayette District Well Operations Supervisor along with plans to prevent future incidents

source.title: Personnel Handling Incident - Man Rider Uncontrolled Descent

context.region: Gulf of America, Green Canyon Block 432

actions_taken: Employee evacuated via medivac to onshore medical facility
Joint investigation conducted with winch manufacturer technicians
BSEE onsite investigation performed on February 24, 2025
event.summary: On February 17, 2025, an Expro Americas Inc. employee was using a man rider on the Noble Globetrotter 1 drillship to access the Coil Tubing Lift Frame at approximately 100 feet to tighten a leaking hydraulic hose. After completing the task, the man rider began descending at an accelerated uncontrolled rate. The hoist operator attempted to stop the descent by moving controls to hoist position and reaching for the emergency stop, but the employee reached the rig floor before the stop could be activated. Investigation revealed the OEM Programming and Control Logic had been altered from Default to Warning settings, bypassing critical safety systems including slack line detection, travel limits, and encoder performance monitoring. This prevented the load brakes from engaging. Environmental degradation of the drive motor and encoder, inadequate preventive maintenance, and insufficient third-party inspections were contributing factors. The employee was medically cleared for full duty.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Lifting Incident - Noble Drillship Blackhornet - Green Canyon Block 584

context.region: Gulf of America - Green Canyon Block 584

actions_taken: Both injured personnel evacuated to University Hospital in New Orleans
BSEE Houma District office notified orally and written report submitted within 15 days
Onsite investigation conducted on January 3, 2025
Multiple tests conducted with magnetic lifting device and plate

event.summary: On December 25, 2024, a 340 lbs steel plate fell from a defective magnetic heavy lifting device on the Noble Drillship Blackhornet, striking two workers on their left feet. The welder (IP1) and roustabout (IP2) were lowering the plate when it prematurely disengaged from the magnetic lifting device, falling 47 inches. Both workers suffered swelling and contusions and were evacuated to hospital. Investigation revealed the magnetic lifting device had damaged pole shoes creating air gaps that reduced lifting capacity. Contributing factors included inadequate JSA, failure to conduct timeout for safety, employee perceived haste, and inadequate hazard identification.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations issue a safety alert/bulletin regarding this incident

source.title: Lifting Incident - Deepwater Invictus - Green Canyon Block 868

context.region: Gulf of America - Green Canyon Block 868

actions_taken: Task suspended and area secured
Bridge notified
IP escorted to rig hospital
IP evacuated by medivac helicopter to University Hospital New Orleans
TOI assembled investigation team
BSEE onsite investigation conducted June 10, 2025
event.summary: On May 8, 2025, two Transocean engineers were transferring nine sections of Hawse piping to a storage rack on the Deepwater Invictus drillship. After placing the eighth pipe section on the top tier, the 2nd Engineer left to retrieve a U-bolt while the 3rd Engineer began rigging the next pipe. The unsecured pipe section rolled off the rack, fell approximately 3 feet, and crushed the 3rd Engineer's right middle finger, resulting in fingertip amputation at the DIP joint. The incident was caused by failure to secure the pipe before removing lifting equipment, inadequate hazard identification in the pre-job briefing, and flawed storage rack design.
recommendations: BSEE Office of Safety Management to evaluate the Hazard ID Prompt Card (HIPC) used by Transocean
Install improvements to rack design including chalks, bumpers, grooves on supports
Increase angle of rack supports
Develop written job procedures for pipe transfer tasks
Improve hazard analysis to identify specific pinch points and crush hazards
Ensure pipes are secured before removing lifting equipment

HIPC did not identify hazard of unsecured pipes rolling

After reviewing the HIPC, BSEE found it to be inadequate. Although, the HIPC did identify pinch points as a hazard, the HIPC did not specify where the hazard existed
The HIPC failed to recognize unsecured pipe rolling off the rack creating a potential crush point
