source.title: Accident Investigation Report - GI 47 AP Platform Gas Release Incident

context.region: Gulf of America, Grand Isle Block 47

actions_taken: IP evacuated from platform by helicopter
Field paramedic flown in from nearby platform
IP transported to Medical Center for evaluation
X-Rays and CT scans performed
Drug and alcohol screening performed
IP re-evaluated at Urgent Care on 28 April 2025
GOM Shelf conducted internal investigation
BSEE investigation initiated on 08 May 2025
event.summary: On 25 April 2025 at approximately 1330 hours, a Louisiana Safety Systems Valve Technician was replacing trim and seal in a control valve on a 6-inch gas line at GI 47 AP platform. While disassembling the valve, a sudden gas release occurred causing the valve bonnet flange assembly (approximately 50 pounds) to strike the technician in the chest and abdomen, knocking him backwards onto the scaffolding deck. The technician sustained an anterior rib fracture of the 8th left rib and a laceration behind his ear. Investigation revealed the gas line had approximately 143 psi pressure (SCADA data showed pressure drop from 143 psi to 15 psi in 20 seconds). The technician failed to obtain proper permits, did not follow manufacturer recommendations for valve disassembly, worked on unapproved scaffolding without fall protection, and the Person-in-Charge did not verify energy isolation before work commenced.
recommendations: Management to meet with GI 47 AP leadership to review learnings and contributing factors
Site leadership must ensure tasks involving pressurized systems are authorized by PIC with appropriate documentation prior to work beginning
Site leadership must ensure third-party service personnel working on pressurized systems are accompanied by operations group member to verify double-block and bleed and line bleed down
Scaffolding contractors to include red caution tape around erected scaffolding as additional visual indicator structure is not ready for use
Task JSA development to include collective discussion of all possible hazards and proper mitigation
Task JSAs should include mitigation of employing four nuts maintained on bolts to prevent flange dislodgement by unforeseen pressure releases
Management to develop, distribute, and verify field-leadership review of Safety Alert describing case findings
BSEE New Orleans District recommends Office of Incident Investigations consider issuing a Safety Alert

threats.name: Failure to verify energy isolation before maintenance
Trapped pressure in gas line from previous work
Failure to follow manufacturer valve disassembly procedure
Inadequate communication between PIC and contractor

consequences.name: Personnel injury from valve component ejection

controls.name: Energy Isolation Permit
controls.barrier_role: Verify line is depressurized before maintenance
controls.lod_basis: Primary procedural control to prevent work on energized systems

supporting_text: The IP did not obtain the PIC's signature on the LSS JSA, the GOM Shelf Energy Isolation Permit to ensure the line was free of pressure

The IP failed to acquire permission from the PIC to begin work on control valve, failed to acquire a Working from Heights Permit and failed to have the PIC issue an Energy Isolation Permit for the work being performed

While there was an Energy Isolation Permit that was issued on 25 April 2025, GOM Shelf stated that the permit was issued for different valves that were being replaced, not the valve the IP was working on

controls.name: Job Safety Analysis (JSA) Review and Approval
controls.barrier_role: Identify hazards and controls before work begins
controls.lod_basis: Primary planning control to identify and mitigate hazards

supporting_text: According to GOM Shelf's investigation, the PIC of the platform never signed off on the JSA for the IP to begin work
The PIC admitted to signing the LSS Valve Technician's JSA after the incident occurred rather than before the job began
The IP's LSS Valve Technician JSA should have been reviewed by both the PIC of the platform and the IP before the job began

controls.name: Pressure Verification via Analog Gauge
controls.barrier_role: Verify zero pressure before valve disassembly
controls.lod_basis: Secondary verification of energy isolation

supporting_text: The IP verified that the 6-inch gas line's analog gauge indicated that there was zero pressure in the line
The SCADA data taken from the Daniel's Meter on the 6-inch gas line upstream of the control valve indicated that there was 143 psi on the 6-inch gas line at the time of the gas release
The IP stated that he verified the analog pressure gauge on the line indicated that there was zero pressure on the line

controls.name: Needle Valve Bleed-off
controls.barrier_role: Relieve trapped pressure between isolation valves
controls.lod_basis: Secondary pressure relief mechanism

supporting_text: The IP then opened two needle valves, one on each side of the control valve, to allow any pressure that was in between the valves to be relieved
The IP stated that there were no signs of fluid or pressure coming out of the needle valves when opened
This information indicates that after the line was bled down, it still had approximately 160 PSI remaining in the gas line on 25 April 2025

controls.name: Manufacturer Valve Disassembly Procedure
controls.barrier_role: Prevent valve component ejection during disassembly
controls.lod_basis: Procedural control for safe valve maintenance

supporting_text: The IP failed to follow manufacturer recommendations while working on the control valve
The IP failed to keep 4 nuts on the studs of the bonnet flange, which would prevent the possibility of the bonnet flange being forced upwards due to an unforeseen pressure release
The manufacturer recommends that during maintenance, the hex nuts or cap screws attaching the bonnet to the valve body should have been loosened approximately 3 mm or 1/8 inch
Task JSAs should include the mitigation of employing the usage four (4) nuts maintained on bolts to prevent a flange and/or components from being dislodged by unforeseen pressure releases

controls.name: Working at Heights Permit
controls.barrier_role: Ensure fall protection and safe scaffolding use
controls.lod_basis: Primary control for work above 6 feet

supporting_text: The IP did not obtain the PIC's signature on the LSS JSA, the GOM Shelf Energy Isolation Permit to ensure the line was free of pressure, or the Working at Heights Permit that is required when working above 6 feet of the main deck surface

Because the IP did not receive permission to work at heights during the work being performed, the IP used an unapproved scaffolding platform that was identified with a white tag by the Competent Scaffold Builder
The IP failed to acquire a Working from Heights Permit

controls.name: Fall Protection Equipment (Full Body Harness and Retractable Lifeline)
controls.barrier_role: Prevent injury from fall when working at heights
controls.lod_basis: Personal protective equipment as last line of defense against falls

supporting_text: The IP also failed to utilize the required fall-protection of a full body harness along with a retractable lifeline
The IP did not utilize the required fall protection while working 6 feet or higher from the main deck

This breakdown in communication allowed for the IP to commence work on a gas line that had not been deemed safe by the PIC or verified as having zero pressure on the line prior to commencing work. The IP also should have been more aware of the hazards associated with the maintenance of the control valve

controls.name: Approved Scaffolding with Safety Features
controls.barrier_role: Provide safe working platform at height
controls.lod_basis: Primary physical control for safe elevated work

supporting_text: The IP used an unapproved scaffolding platform that was identified with a white tag by the Competent Scaffold Builder. The white tag indicated that the scaffolding was not safe to use as it was missing a ladder for entry and kick plates
The use of the scaffolding should have been addressed prior to the IP utilizing it to perform the maintenance on the control valve

Scaffolding contractors will be requested, in addition to posting the required inspection tag on the scaffolding, to include red caution tape around erected scaffolding as an additional visual indicator that the structure is not ready for use

controls.name: PIC Authorization and Supervision
controls.barrier_role: Ensure work is authorized and hazards are communicated
controls.lod_basis: Primary management control over work activities

supporting_text: According to the PIC, the IP did not have his (the PIC's) authorization to begin the work on the control valve located on the 6-inch gas line

The PIC and contractor (IP) did not communicate prior to the IP starting his work on the 6-inch gas line. Had communication been better, the IP would not have been able to start work without the PIC's approval
The PIC of the GI 47 AP facility should have also been more aware of the operations taking place on the platform
Site leadership must ensure, through clear communication to service providers, that task(s) involving pressurized systems must be authorized by the PIC

controls.name: Double-Block and Bleed Verification by Operations Personnel
controls.barrier_role: Verify isolation and depressurization of line
controls.lod_basis: Independent verification of energy isolation

supporting_text: By the IP failing to have the PIC verify energy isolation before commencing work, the trapped pressure in the 6-inch line went unidentified while the IP was performing maintenance on the control valve

Site leadership must ensure that third (3rd) party service personnel who are asked to work on pressurized systems or valves are accompanied by a member of operations group to walk the task down, verify the ability and execution of double-block and bleed and verification of the line bled down

controls.name: Field Paramedic Response
controls.barrier_role: Provide immediate medical assessment and treatment
controls.lod_basis: Emergency response to minimize injury severity

supporting_text: A field paramedic then flew from GI 43 platform to GI 47 AP platform to evaluate and treat the IP
Upon arrival at GI 47 AP, the field paramedic found the IP awake, alert, and stable, complaining of an aching pain on the left-side of his abdomen and chest area
The paramedic stated that the IP would have to be sent to an onshore medical facility to have further evaluations performed

controls.name: Emergency Evacuation Procedures
controls.barrier_role: Transport injured personnel to medical facilities
controls.lod_basis: Emergency response to provide definitive medical care

supporting_text: The IP was flown by helicopter to shore where he was then transported by an ambulance to Medical Center for further evaluation
The IP's Health, Safety and Environment (HSE) representative was notified of the incident and arranged for an ambulance to meet the IP at the heliport in Galliano, Louisiana

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - High Island A 379 B Platform Confined Space Entry Incident

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - High Island Area Block A 379

actions_taken: CPR administered for approximately 20 minutes
IP evacuated by Medivac helicopter to Galveston hospital
IP placed in Intensive Care Unit for 3 days
BSEE on-site investigation conducted September 8, 2023
event.summary: On September 4, 2023, at approximately 09:15 hours on High Island A 379 B platform, an injured person (IP) entered a Heater Treater vessel (NBK-1070) to clean it while wearing only an Air Purifying Respirator instead of a Supplied Air Respirator. The IP was overcome by fumes and found face down in fluids/sludge, not breathing with no pulse. Two supervisors entered without respirators to rescue the IP. CPR was administered for 20 minutes before the IP was revived. The incident resulted from multiple failures to follow the confined space entry plan including: no tri-gas monitoring, no hole watch, no rescue equipment setup, improper PPE, no entry permit, and inadequate training. The operator also failed to accurately report the severity of the incident to BSEE.
recommendations: Ensure all Subcontractors adhere to work plans
Ensure all Company and Subcontracted personnel are properly trained before prior to task/work is started
Ensure accurate incident reporting is made, to include follow up reports

source.title: Crane Boom Damage Incident - High Island A 382 F

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - High Island Area Block A 382

actions_taken: Crane Operator immediately shut the crane down
Crane Mechanic was informed
Crane was taken out of service
Apache Corporation retraining Crane Operator
event.summary: On June 2, 2023, at 12:30 hours, during crane operations at High Island A 382 F facility, the crane boom contacted the boom stop when raised to too high an angle, causing damage to the boom heel section cords. The Crane Operator was focusing on booming up and holding the ball level when the load block swung into the crane boom. The High Angle Kick Out limit switch failed to stop the boom from booming up too far. The incident resulted in $50,000 in estimated replacement costs with no injuries or pollution. The investigation concluded that Crane Operator inattentiveness of the boom angle was the primary cause, with the failure of the high angle kick out safety system as a contributing factor.
recommendations: Apache Corporation is Retraining Crane Operator

source.title: Structural Damage - Firewater System Failure - Horn Mountain Platform

context.region: Gulf of America, Mississippi Canyon Block 127
context.operator: Occidental Petroleum (operated for Anadarko Petroleum Corporation)

event.incident_type: Firewater System Rupture with Dropped Object
actions_taken: Emergency shutdown initiated automatically
Fire water pumps A and B automatically started
Personnel mustered at designated locations
Emergency generator loaded
Fire water pumps shut down after ESD event
Jockey water pump manually started by CRO
Fire water pumps restarted causing water hammer
Fire water pumps shut down after rupture
event.summary: On May 9, 2025, at approximately 1530 hours, a water hammer event occurred in the firewater system piping at the Horn Mountain SPAR platform in Mississippi Canyon Block 127. The incident began when an EnerMech technician accidentally initiated an ESD while troubleshooting an air compressor by turning the Bypass Rig Air switch, causing the TSE system to lose pressure. Following the ESD, multiple procedural failures and equipment issues occurred: the jockey water pump failed to automatically restart due to breaker issues, the T-gen ran out of fuel because SDV 2082 was not opened, and a suspected leaking check valve allowed the firewater main pressure to drop. When the main fire water pumps were restarted without first bleeding air from the system through helideck hose reels, a water hammer effect ruptured the FiberBond piping in multiple locations. A 1.5-pound metal support clamp broke loose and fell 30 feet, landing 5-6 feet from a worker near Lifeboat 4. The incident resulted in $250,000 in damage to the firewater system, including 3 failed gaskets, 2 piping joint leaks, 3 piping elbow leaks, 2 T-piping leaks, 3 piping spool leaks, and 1 wear at spool. No injuries occurred.
recommendations: Update Power Generation System Procedure to include opening SDV 2082 after ESD events
Correct Firewater System Operating Procedure to reference PCV 6650 instead of non-existent Sea Chest Valve
Update Power Protection and Life Support Systems Procedures to reflect current JWP configuration
Ensure helideck hose reels are opened to bleed air before restarting fire water pumps
Replace or repair leaking check valve FSV 6650-004
Review all operating procedures to ensure alignment with current platform configuration
Add additional equipment to prevent similar incidents

threats.name: Accidental ESD Initiation
Loss of Firewater System Pressure
Air Ingress into Firewater System
Water Hammer Event
Equipment Failure - Leaking Check Valve

controls.name: Temperature Safety Element (TSE) Loop Monitoring
controls.barrier_role: Detection and alarm system for abnormal conditions
controls.lod_basis: Automatic detection system designed to identify loss of pressure and initiate protective actions

supporting_text: At 1455 hours, an ESD was initiated in Zone 14 of the platform due to the Temperature Safety Element (TSE) loop losing pressure

controls.name: Automatic Fire Water Pump Startup on ESD
controls.barrier_role: Automatic response to maintain firefighting capability during emergency
controls.lod_basis: Automatic system response without human intervention

supporting_text: Simultaneously, at 1455 hours, the Fire Water Pumps (FWP) A and B along with the Emergency Generator (E-Gen) automatically started, as designed

controls.name: Jockey Water Pump Automatic Startup
controls.barrier_role: Maintain firewater system pressure automatically
controls.lod_basis: Automatic pressure maintenance system

supporting_text: After the FWPs were shut off, the Jockey Water Pump (JWP) did not automatically start to maintain firewater main pressure due to the 2E-52 Breaker not being closed to power the AMCC 2001 Buss
At 1514 hours, an Occidental platform mechanic discovered that the firewater main had low pressure. The Mechanic stated that the JWP should have already been running

controls.name: Check Valve FSV 6650-004
controls.barrier_role: Prevent backflow and maintain system pressure
controls.lod_basis: Passive mechanical device to prevent reverse flow

supporting_text: This caused the JWP to lose power once again, causing the water pressure to drop, likely due to a leaking check valve (FSV 6650-004). This check valve was stated in Anadarko's internal investigation as having a history of leaks
EQUIPMENT FAILURE: Inadequate equipment repair- Suspected leaking check valve. Anadarko states that in their internal investigation report that there is history of leaking check valves in the FW Main

controls.name: Firewater System Operating Procedure
controls.barrier_role: Provide correct instructions for safe firewater system operation
controls.lod_basis: Procedural guidance requiring human interpretation and execution

supporting_text: The current firewater startup procedure references opening a Sea Chest Valve which does not exist. As such, the FWP startup procedure should have referenced opening the PCV 6650, not the Sea Chest Valve

The firewater hose reels were never opened to allow an escape route for the air that was trapped in the system. Had the firewater hose reels been opened, as called for in the procedures, it would have allowed the air to be purged out of the system

Lastly, the CRO did not follow the Firewater System Operating procedure in place and failed to request the opening of the helideck hose reels to bleed the air from the system prior to starting the FWPs
MANAGEMENT SYSTEM: Inadequate written job procedures- Incorrect/ inaccurate operating procedures in place for the specific ESD event
COMMUNICATION: Instructions not understood and not followed- Correct Fire Water system procedure was not followed

controls.name: Power Generation System Procedure
controls.barrier_role: Ensure proper power restoration after ESD events
controls.lod_basis: Procedural guidance for power system recovery

supporting_text: At 1524 hours, the T-gen ran out of diesel due to the Shut Down Valve (SDV) 2082 being in the closed position, as the SDV 2082 valve was never opened after the ESD event to supply the T-gen with fuel

One of the procedures that was not properly identified included not opening the SDV 2082 valve for the T-gen after the ESD event, which caused the T-gen to lose power due to lack of fuel at an important time during the event. This step was not listed in the procedure

controls.name: Power Protection and Life Support Systems Procedures
controls.barrier_role: Guide proper operation of jockey water pump system
controls.lod_basis: Procedural guidance for critical life support systems

supporting_text: There was also a failure to restart the JWP in order to provide a prime for the water main system. This occurred due to the Power Protection and Life Support System procedures not being updated to reflect the use of a JWP that the platform is equipped with currently

controls.name: Control Room Operator Oversight
controls.barrier_role: Monitor and control firewater system operations
controls.lod_basis: Human supervision and decision-making during operations

supporting_text: At 1512 hours, the Occidental Control Room Operator (CRO) requested that both FWPs be shut down because the ESD event was over
At 1530 hours, the Mechanic that originally noticed the low water main pressure received a call from the CRO requesting him to start the FWPs
The CRO concurred and the JWP was started by the CRO

Lastly, the CRO did not follow the Firewater System Operating procedure in place and failed to request the opening of the helideck hose reels to bleed the air from the system prior to starting the FWPs

controls.name: Contractor Work Permit and Supervision
controls.barrier_role: Control and supervise contractor activities to prevent inadvertent system impacts
controls.lod_basis: Procedural control over third-party work activities

supporting_text: At 1132 hours, the Rig Up/Rig down Pre-test Sub-Sea Commissioning Spread permit was approved and the permit state was live

An internal investigation revealed that during troubleshooting of the air compressor, an EnerMech technician accidentally turned the Bypass Rig Air switch on the compressor which caused the TSE system to lose pressure, initiating the ESD event
HUMAN ERROR: Inexperience knowledge of equipment operation- EnerMech not familiar with the operations of the air compressor system installed on the facility

controls.name: Piping Support Clamps
controls.barrier_role: Secure piping to prevent dropped objects
controls.lod_basis: Physical restraint system to prevent equipment falling

supporting_text: Due to the piping rupturing and releasing seawater into the Gulf of America, a metal clamp, weighing approximately 1.5 pounds, that was supporting the piping broke loose and fell to the main deck
The metal clamp fell 30 feet and landed approximately 5-6 feet from an individual who was near the lifeboat

controls.name: Muster System and Personnel Accountability
controls.barrier_role: Ensure personnel safety during emergency events
controls.lod_basis: Procedural response to emergency requiring human action

supporting_text: During troubleshooting, the Technician noticed that the air from the platform air system was bypassing the starter for the compressor. The Technician and his supervisor then heard the platform muster alarm sound and the platform's flare ignited. They both went to their appropriate muster locations and stood by for further instructions
The metal clamp fell 30 feet and landed approximately 5-6 feet from an individual who was near the lifeboat

controls.name: Emergency Generator Auto-Start
controls.barrier_role: Provide backup power during emergency shutdown
controls.lod_basis: Automatic backup system without human intervention

supporting_text: Simultaneously, at 1455 hours, the Fire Water Pumps (FWP) A and B along with the Emergency Generator (E-Gen) automatically started, as designed
Personnel were then dispatched to load the E-Gen and get the Air Compressors started on the platform. The E-Gen was successfully loaded

source.title: Structural Damage - Crane Lifting Incident at Horn Mountain SPAR

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi Canyon Block 127

actions_taken: All-stop called immediately
Job stand-down initiated

event.summary: On 21 October 2023 at 13:04 hours, platform personnel at Horn Mountain SPAR attempted to lift an 8,300-pound hydraulic chain jack cylinder using the West Crane. When the lift reached 15 feet above deck, two nylon choker slings failed due to contact with sharp edges on the cylinder, causing the load to fall onto two cargo baskets. The lifting authorities had decided not to use the manufacturer-recommended lifting pad-eyes, believing them to be frozen after 22 years in service. Instead, they used nylon choker slings wrapped around the cylinder body. The shorter slings used for this lift were positioned where they contacted sharp edges at the top of the jack, causing them to cut and fail. No personnel injuries occurred, and damage was limited to two cargo baskets. The incident could have been prevented by using the dedicated lifting pad-eyes as recommended by the manufacturer.
recommendations: Recommend OII draft safety alert to inform operators to utilize proper lifting techniques as recommended by the manufacturer
key_phrases: sharp edge near the top of the jack

threats.name: Rigging equipment failure due to sharp edge contact
Use of non-manufacturer recommended lifting method

source.title: BSEE Accident Investigation Report - Noble Stanley Lafosse Drillship Blackout and EDS Activation

context.region: Gulf of America, Mississippi Canyon Block 300

event.incident_type: Loss of station keeping leading to Emergency Disconnect Sequence activation and discharge of drilling fluids
actions_taken: Manual activation of Emergency Disconnect Sequence (EDS)
Shearing of 5.875 in. drill pipe
Detachment of Lower Marine Riser Package (LMRP)
Restoration of diesel generators and thrusters
Installation of barrier covers over emergency fuel shut off valves

event.summary: On March 28, 2025, an able body seaman (AB1) aboard the Noble Stanley Lafosse drillship mistakenly operated emergency fuel shut off valve switches instead of accommodation fire dampener switches during routine preventative maintenance. This error caused all diesel generators to trip sequentially, resulting in a total blackout and loss of dynamic positioning. The drillship drifted off station, triggering a manual Emergency Disconnect Sequence that sheared the drill pipe and released 2,436 barrels of drilling brine into the Gulf of America. The incident caused $2.6 million in damage to subsea equipment. Contributing factors included failure to conduct a required Task Risk Assessment, AB1 working alone without adequate supervision, self-perceived time pressure, and lack of physical barriers protecting critical emergency fuel shut off valves.
recommendations: Install barrier covers over emergency fuel shut off valves to prevent inadvertent operation
Ensure Task Risk Assessments are completed prior to all work tasks as per company policy
Provide adequate supervision and pairing of personnel for critical maintenance tasks
Reinforce Stop Work Authority culture and procedures
key_phrases: mistakenly operating the wrong switch panel
felt self-perceived pressure and rushed through the task
TRA was not performed until after the incident occurred
emergency fuel shut off valves were not protected with barriers or warning signs
Failure to execute Stop Work Authority
did not verify dampener line-item numbers

context.region: Gulf of America, Mississippi Canyon Block 300

event.summary: On May 29, 2025, at approximately 10:46 a.m., the Noble Stanley Lafosse Drillship experienced an unexpected change in wind speed and direction due to strong thunderstorms while preparing for cementing operations at Mississippi Canyon Block 300. Wind gusts reached 60 knots with waterspouts impacting the vessel, causing a 14-meter excursion while hanging off 5-7/8 inch drill pipe. The crew initiated an Emergency Disconnect Sequence, successfully closing blind shear rams and securing the well. The incident resulted in the discharge of 417 barrels of 10.9 ppg calcium chloride brine to the sea. No injuries were reported.
recommendations: Enhance weather detection capabilities
Refine operational readiness during critical phases
Continuously improve emergency response protocols

consequences.name: Discharge of Drilling Fluids to Sea

source.title: Structural Damage - Emergency Disconnect Sequence Event

event.summary: On March 5, 2024, at 04:15 hrs, the Transocean Deepwater Poseidon drillship experienced extreme unexpected changes in wind speed and direction due to strong thunderstorms while drilling the AW003 well in Mississippi Canyon Block 391. Wind speeds rapidly increased from 30 kts to 83 kts with multiple directional shifts (South to West to North), causing vessel excursion beyond the red watch circle limit of 90.3 ft. An Emergency Disconnect Sequence was initiated, resulting in release of approximately 2,875 bbls of synthetic based mud to the seafloor. During the EDS event, three joints of 6-5/8 in pipe and an MPD bearing (total weight ~13,200 lbs) fell from the derrick onto the driller's shack, causing structural damage. This falling pipe incident was not initially disclosed to BSEE and was only discovered during a subsequent inspection on June 24, 2024.

source.title: Pollution Event - Na Kika Platform MC 474-A

context.region: Gulf of America, Mississippi Canyon Block 474

actions_taken: Chemical trial halted on 14 February 2025
Reverted to original emulsion breaker formula
Protocol sampling initiated
Incident reported to BSEE on 20 February 2025
event.summary: On 08 February 2025, a pollution event occurred at the Na Kika platform when a trial emulsion breaker chemical caused frothing/foaming in the produced water treatment system. This led to faulty level readings, liquid carryover in vessels, and discharge of approximately 89 barrels of oil into Gulf of America waters over a 7-day period (08-15 February 2025). The discharge exceeded the daily maximum limit of 42 mg/l. BP personnel did not immediately realize the oil discharge was occurring. Once identified, the chemical trial was stopped and the original emulsion breaker formula was reinstated, successfully ending the sheening.
recommendations: BSEE Production Operations Support Section should reach out to industry to require additional safeguards to improve detection time when system upsets occur
Operators should have methods in place to detect pollution events besides visual observation, given that produced water outlets are located well below the water surface
key_phrases: pollution event went unnoticed for 7 days

threats.name: Incompatible chemical introduction causing process upset
Frothing/foaming in production vessels
Faulty level readings due to foam
Liquid carryover in separation vessels

consequences.name: Oil discharge to Gulf of America waters

source.title: Dropped Cleanout Assembly - Diamond Ocean BlackHornet

event.summary: On June 7, 2023, at 11:00 hours, a 43-foot cleanout assembly fell approximately 40 feet onto the pipe skate on the Diamond Ocean BlackHornet Drillship during drilling operations. The incident occurred because incorrect elevator inserts (4.5 inch EU instead of 4.5 inch IEU) were installed and the Driller and Assistant Driller failed to follow procedures and complete the Elevator Pre-use Checklist. A floor hand was in the red zone operating the pipe skate remotely at the time of the incident but was not injured. The incorrect inserts initially held hard-banded pipe successfully but failed when lifting non-hard-banded pipe.

threats.name: Incorrect elevator insert size installed
Failure to complete pre-use inspection checklist

consequences.name: Personnel injury or fatality - floor hand in red zone

controls.lod_basis: Primary procedural control to verify equipment configuration before use

supporting_text: Elevator Pre-Use Checklist (ref# CHKL/001) was not filled out for this operation
This checklist had two items to verify the correct inserts are used: 1) Verify the size of the pipe that the elevators are to be used with. 2) Physically measure the internal bore of the elevators
Due to the Driller and Assistant Driller not following the guidelines and procedures and not filling out the checklist...the incorrect inserts were installed

The Assistant Driller took a glance at the size and observed 4-1/2 inch stamped on the inserts
Drill Pipe Elevators Guideline (5.1.4.8.a) Designate the Assistant Driller as the responsible person to carry out the checks
The Assistant Driller was not aware of his responsibility to ensure that the Elevator Pre-use Checklist was completed

controls.lod_basis: Supervisory verification to confirm first-line checks completed

It is the Driller's responsibility to verify that the above checks have been carried out to his satisfaction
The Driller did not verify that the Elevator Pre-use Checklist was carried out to his satisfaction
The Driller and Assistant Driller did not follow the guidelines and procedures

source.title: Fire Incident on Floating Production Unit - MC 547 A Who Dat

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi Canyon Block 547

event.top_event: Loss of Containment - Oil Release and Ignition

event.summary: On 24 December 2023 at approximately 0743 hours, a fire occurred on a rental air compressor used for blasting and painting operations on the Who Dat floating production unit in MC 547 A. The fire was caused by failure of a 90° elbow on the oil separator piping, which sprayed oil onto hot surfaces within the air compressor enclosure, igniting the oil. The platform's ESD system activated, shutting in the facility. The fire was extinguished by the Lead Operator and Fire Team using water monitors, deluge system, and hose reels. The CO2 fire suppression system in the adjacent generator enclosure activated as designed. No injuries, environmental impact, or platform damage occurred. The rental air compressor sustained fire damage and was removed for repairs costing $31,969.09.
recommendations: No recommendations issued by BSEE New Orleans District

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Structural Damage - Mississippi Canyon 582 A (Medusa)

event.summary: On 16 April 2025 at approximately 1500 hours on the Medusa SPAR platform, a 15-pound cable roller (66 inches long, 1 inch diameter) broke off from an out-of-service crane boom and fell approximately 50 feet to the deck below, striking and damaging a hydraulic hose. The cable roller had major corrosion identified during the October 2022 annual crane inspection with recommendations to repair or replace within 1-3 months, but the repairs were never completed. No barricades were installed to prevent personnel from entering the drop zone beneath the crane during repositioning operations. No injuries occurred, but the incident had potential for serious injury or fatality.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations should consider issuing a Safety Alert regarding the incident
Address corrosion issues discovered during annual crane inspections promptly
Install barricades or other means to prevent personnel from entering drop zone areas when work with dropped object potential is being performed
JSAs should provide more thorough description of possible dropped objects and require barricading the work area prior to performing work on cranes
Remove crane boom from facility to eliminate possibility of additional components falling

possibility of a serious injury or fatality

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Mississippi Canyon Block 607

event.summary: On March 19, 2024, at 13:30 hrs, during BOP deployment and riser running operations on the Valaris DS-18 drillship, riser joint #31 was being hoisted approximately 30 feet above the rig floor when the riser cart shuttle failed to freewheel due to a loose brake wire causing a fuse to blow. The hydraulic brake did not release, causing the riser flange to be pulled out of the cart shuttle. The Cameron Hydraulic Riser Running Tool (HRRT) removable shank mandrel parted under shock load, and the riser joint fell back onto the riser cart, damaging the skate tailing arms, skate lift bucket, HRRT, and riser joint floatation. No injuries occurred. Estimated damage: $418,000.
recommendations: Improve job template detail on inspection of all load path components of the HRRT

source.title: Nitrogen Bottle Rupture - Helix Q5000

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Mississippi Canyon Block 727
context.operator: Kosmos Energy Gulf of Mexico Operations

event.top_event: Loss of Containment - Pressure Vessel Rupture
actions_taken: Safety standdown initiated at 16:14
General alarm sounded at 16:41
Full muster completed at 16:54
Airgas HAZMAT response team vented cylinders starting at 22:16
Three injured personnel evaluated by rig medic and cleared to return to work
Operator plans to install nitrogen generation system in 2025 budget
Helix plans to install physical barrier and hard piping
Vendor change implemented
event.summary: On June 5, 2024, at approximately 15:38 hours, a nitrogen cylinder ruptured inside a twelve-cylinder bottle rack onboard the Helix Q5000 during workover operations. The rupture was caused by severe corrosion that reduced wall thickness from 0.25 inches to 0.075 inches at the bottom of the bottle, which contained approximately 2,400 psi. The rupture damaged other cylinders in the rack and scattered them across the main deck. Three personnel staging equipment nearby sustained minor injuries from shrapnel. The incident resulted in $29,000 in damage to 2 nitrogen racks and an umbilical. Investigation revealed inadequate corrosion protection from water-based paint coating, insufficient inspection protocols that did not include disassembly for thorough examination, poor rack design allowing metal-to-metal contact, and lack of drainage causing prolonged exposure to corrosive marine environment.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends Office of Incident Investigations consider a Safety Alert to warn industry about the risk that these bottle racks pose
Install nitrogen generation system to eliminate reliance on external rental systems
Install physical barrier and hard piping to mitigate exposure to personnel and equipment during potential future failures
Change vendor and adhere to elevated inspection process
Implement inspection protocols that include disassembly for thorough examination of individual cylinders and manifold components
Use corrosion-resistant coatings suitable for marine environment
Design racks with proper drainage and material barriers between cylinders and rack structure

threats.name: Corrosion of pressure vessel wall
Mechanical damage from metal-to-metal contact
Prolonged exposure to corrosive marine environment

controls.barrier_role: Corrosion protection
controls.lod_basis: Primary physical barrier against corrosion

The water-based paint coating on the cylinders did not effectively prevent corrosion in the marine environment

controls.lod_basis: Independent verification and inspection

supporting_text: the nitrogen cylinder rack adhered to Department of Transportation (DOT) special permit regulations, which mandate a 10-year hydrostatic or ultrasonic examination. However, these inspections failed to identify critical issues such as excessive corrosion with the internal cylinders

controls.barrier_role: Pre-operational integrity check
controls.lod_basis: Verification before use

supporting_text: visual pre-fill inspections were performed prior to deployment of the bottles to offshore locations, they did not involve disassembly of the rack for a comprehensive evaluation of the individual cylinders and manifold components

Visual pre-fill inspections were conducted prior to mobilization offshore, but the rack was not disassembled for a thorough inspection of the individual cylinders or manifold components. This type of inspection did not allow for the bottom of the cylinders to be inspected for corrosion

the lack of a protective barrier in the rack's design allowed for metal-to-metal contact between the bottles and the rack, increasing the risk of damage and eventually failure

The lack of drainage in the rack's design left the cylinders exposed to an even greater corrosive environment than the already corrosive marine environment the bottles routinely experienced

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - MC 807 Platform A - Hand Laceration

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Mississippi Canyon Block 807

actions_taken: Onsite medic provided first aid treatment
IP evacuated to onshore medical facility in Morgan City, LA
IP received sutures and released back to duty
IP returned to platform on 26 February 2023
event.summary: On 24 February 2023 at approximately 1115 hours, a Mechanic employed by Helmerich & Payne was attempting to install a hydraulic line on the Pipe Handling Machine (PHM) at Shell's Mars Tension Leg Platform. When the combination wrench being used was determined to be too long to access the fitting, the IP decided to modify the wrench by cutting it shorter with a manual hack saw. The wrench was placed in a vise, and as the IP cut through the final section, his weight shifted causing his hand to come down onto the freshly cut sharp edge, resulting in a laceration between the ring and little finger. The IP was treated onsite, then evacuated for sutures at an onshore medical facility. Investigation found inadequate pre-job planning, lack of supervision, and failure to obtain proper tools as probable causes.
recommendations: The BSEE New Orleans District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time.

event.summary: On January 6, 2023, at 13:00 hours, Shell Offshore Inc. experienced a pollution event at Mississippi Canyon 943 subsea well PN003-ST2-BP1, which is tied back to MC 807 B (Olympus). While attempting to open the Surface-Controlled Subsurface Safety Valve (SCSSV), there was an inability to build pressure in the SCSSV control lines and abnormal pressure behavior at the tubing and A-annulus head. An underwater ROV confirmed liquid being released to the environment through the High Pressure vent on the tree due to SCSSV control lines loss of integrity. The fluid mixture consisted of hydraulic fluid, methanol, calcium bromide completion brine, and synthetic based oil. Initial estimate was 9.26 gallons, later updated to 16.61 barrels total. The ROV closed control valves SV1 and SV2, stopping the leak. The well remains shut in with 2 barriers and pressure is being continuously monitored. The tubing is suspected to be parted at a shallow depth along with the SCSSV control lines, allowing a leak path from the wellbore to the SCSSV control lines to the HP vent.
recommendations: Shell to perform intervention to remove tubing for analysis
Shell to identify causes of failure after tubing recovery
BSEE to engage with Shell's analysis to inform policy and procedure to prevent future reoccurrence

tubing suspected to be parted at shallow depth
leak path from wellbore to SCSSV control lines to HP vent
inability to build pressure in SCSSV control lines

event.summary: On 23 February 2025 at approximately 0830 hours at Mississippi Canyon 809 Platform A (Ursa), a SafeZone worker slipped backwards while securing felt and cleaning inside a Pressurized Welding Enclosure. The worker's right leg contacted a jagged edge of an I-beam, resulting in a 3-to-4-inch laceration. The worker fell 12-18 inches from an upper to lower level, insufficient to deploy fall protection equipment. The worker was medically evacuated and received 11 staples and 4 stitches. Investigation found inadequate hazard identification during pre-job assessment, lack of supervision, and failure to identify jagged edges and uneven surfaces in the JSA.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations should consider issuing a Safety Alert regarding the incident
Work area should have a more thorough hazard assessment performed
All personnel should be made aware of hazards before starting work
Hazards identified at time of assessment should be mitigated to reduce or eliminate threat to personnel before starting work

event.summary: On March 21, 2023, at approximately 16:45 hours, a rigger was injured during crane operations on the H&P 204 platform rig at Mississippi Canyon 809. The crew was staging a wireline riser (approximately 19 feet in length) with a red gate valve assembly into a transfer basket on the plus 50 level. During a blind lift using radio communication, as the upper end of the assembly was lowered, the lower end shifted and caught the rigger between the pipe and an adjacent basket. The rigger sustained a nondisplaced L4 fracture, traumatic hernia, and pelvic muscle tear. The incident occurred because the Designated Signal Person and rigging crew did not identify the pinch point hazard and the rigger positioned himself in a pinch point location between baskets in a congested workspace.

The Shell Work Permit (URSA-00-5195079) states hard barricades will be installed around the well and hatch, so no barricade was needed in the area where the incident occurred.

The crew members did not follow the recommended Compass card questions/advisories as follows: 1) What are the recommended safe practices to eliminate/safeguard the potential hazards, 2) Everyone has the authority and responsibility to stop work they believe is unsafe and 3) What are the potential hazards?

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi Canyon Block 899

event.incident_type: Pressurized hose release causing personnel injury
actions_taken: Two injured personnel medevaced to New Orleans University Hospital
Both injured personnel released from hospital on Feb 14 and returned to work on Feb 19
Extra whip check installed after incident beneath deck penetration valve and to hose
event.summary: On February 13, 2024, at approximately 22:35 hours on the Transocean Deepwater Proteus drillship at Mississippi Canyon 899, two Tetra filtration crew members were injured when a 6-inch camlock hose connection released under pressure during a leak repair. The crew was flushing deck penetration lines for completion operations. After flushing was completed, a Tetra employee attempted to repair a small leak by releasing the camlock connection levers. Trapped pressure in the line caused the hose to blow off, striking one worker in the face (fractured tooth) and knocking another worker into a pipe (thigh bruising and chemical exposure). Investigation found that the deck valve was closed immediately after pumping stopped, trapping pressure in the line. Proper PPE was not worn, whip checks were not positioned around the camlock connection, and lines were not properly drained before disconnection.
recommendations: The BSEE New Orleans District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time
key_phrases: hose blew off the deck flange
deck valve was immediately closed once pumping was finished
wait for the fluid pressure to leave the lines before closing the valves
whip checks on the 6 inch hoses, but not around the camlock connection
Drain lines before opening camlock connections and bleed off lines before removing hoses

threats.name: Trapped pressure not relieved before disconnection
Premature closure of deck valve trapping pressure
Inadequate hazard identification during flushing operations

controls.name: Procedure to wait for fluid pressure to leave lines before closing valves
controls.barrier_role: Prevent trapped pressure in lines
controls.lod_basis: Operational procedure to prevent pressure buildup

supporting_text: it is common practice when flushing deck penetration lines, and the pump shuts off, that you wait for the fluid pressure to leave the lines before closing the valves. In this case, that didn't happen, and the deck valve was immediately closed once pumping was finished.

controls.name: JSEA requirement to drain lines before opening camlock connections
controls.barrier_role: Ensure pressure is relieved before disconnection
controls.lod_basis: Work procedure checklist

supporting_text: The JSEA collected states: Drain lines before opening camlock connections and bleed off lines before removing hoses.
The deck penetration lines that were flushed were not completely drained and the pressure was not bled before being disconnected.

controls.name: Whip checks positioned around camlock connections
controls.barrier_role: Prevent hose whip from injuring personnel
controls.lod_basis: Physical restraint to contain hose movement

supporting_text: There were whip checks on the 6 inch hoses, but not around the camlock connection being disconnected, to prevent the hose that was being removed from knocking the two injured employees down.
After the incident concluded, and the 6 inch camlock hose was reconnected, there was an extra whip installed. This whip check was attached beneath the deck penetration valve and to the hose.

controls.lod_basis: Last line of defense for personnel protection

supporting_text: The appropriate PPE referenced in the MSDS states requirement of eye protection: wear safety glasses with splash shield or safety goggles/shield and Clothing: wear appropriate chemical resistant clothing and gloves. It was found that only safety glasses were worn during this operation and the chemical resistant clothing or gloves were not worn.

Not wearing the proper PPE (The MSDS states; Eye Protection: wear safety glasses with splash shield or safety goggles/shield and Clothing: wear appropriate chemical resistant clothing and gloves). Only safety glasses were worn during this operation.

supporting_text: The appropriate PPE referenced in the MSDS states requirement of eye protection: wear safety glasses with splash shield or safety goggles/shield

controls.name: Job Safety and Environmental Analysis (JSEA)
controls.barrier_role: Identify hazards and control measures before work
controls.lod_basis: Pre-job planning and hazard identification

supporting_text: There was a Job Safety and Environmental Analysis (JSEA) used for this operation, and it was signed off by the Tetra filtration employees. In the JSEA, there was a checklist of items checked off that referenced: chemical exposure and PPE pressure, and whip checks, bleed off lines before removing, and reviewing the MSDS.
Hazard identification was not appropriately done, hazards with the flushing operations and trapped pressured were not identified or followed.

controls.name: Supervision of PPE compliance
controls.barrier_role: Ensure proper PPE is worn per JSEA and MSDS
controls.lod_basis: Supervisory oversight of work execution

supporting_text: Supervision: Not ensuring the use of the proper PPE. The JSEA reviewed for this operation specified the use of PPE for chemical exposure.

controls.name: Radio communication between Derrick hand and Tetra crew
controls.barrier_role: Coordinate operations and confirm line-ups
controls.lod_basis: Operational communication protocol

supporting_text: He then communicated with the Tetra crew by radio that the valves were lined up.
The Tetra crew informed the Derrick hand by radio they were ready to receive drill water on the out-board side
The Derrick hand then received a phone call and was asked if he had a pump running

controls.name: Double verification of valve line-ups
controls.barrier_role: Ensure correct valve configuration before operations
controls.lod_basis: Verification step in operational procedure

supporting_text: The Transocean Derrick hand stated the valves were lined up to send drill water to the Tetra filter unit, and that he double verified the line-ups.

controls.lod_basis: Passive engineered control

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - MC 941 Platform A Hydrocarbon Release

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi Canyon Block 941

actions_taken: Gas detector activated and platform alarm sounded
Personnel mustered at muster station

event.summary: On 10 May 2023 at approximately 0930 hours, two Grand Isle Shipyard workers were removing bolts from a flange on a 2-inch Well Equalization Header line during a scheduled shut-in at MC 941 Platform A (Titan spar). When loosening the last bolt, trapped pressure from residual fluids in a dog leg bend above the flange was released, spraying both workers in the face with hydrocarbon fluid. A nearby gas detector activated at 0933 hours, triggering platform alarm and muster. No injuries, pollution, or equipment damage occurred. Workers were wearing safety glasses and face shields which prevented injury. Investigation found that the possibility of residual fluids/trapped pressure in the dog leg bend was overlooked despite completion of Simple Isolation Certificate and zero pressure indication on gauge.
recommendations: Review isolations to look for any possibility of hydrocarbon release from doglegs or dead-legs due to residual fluid static pressure remaining after lockout/tagout is completed, even if zero pressure is indicated on the gauge
Implement engineering controls for residual fluids or static pressure release
Review isolations for potential hydrocarbon release from dog-legs or dead-legs even when gauge indicates zero pressure
Utilize appropriate engineering controls for personnel safety

source.title: Mooring Line #9 Failure - Titan SPAR Platform MC 941

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi Canyon Block 941

event.costs: {"amount": 5000000, "currency": "USD", "description": "Replacement cost estimate including engineering work, vessels, materials"}
actions_taken: Production shut in and POB reduced to essential personnel only
Inspection of remaining 3 mooring lines on Port Column
Attempted to increase tension on ML #9 by hauling in anchor chain
ROV inspection to locate H-link connector and chain components
Recovery of anchor chain, H-link, and adjacent links for failure analysis
Metallurgical failure analysis by Stress Engineering Services Inc.
Full investigation by Equinor
Production resumed on 7 July 2023 after BSEE approval
event.summary: On 15 June 2023, during a scheduled ABS UWILD inspection at the Titan SPAR platform (MC 941 A), abnormal slack was observed on Mooring Line #9 with a significant length resting on the seabed. The H-link connector was found buried at the seabed. Investigation revealed the 5-inch Grade RQ4 chain link had parted. Metallurgical analysis concluded the failure was most likely due to fatigue initiating at the top of the crown where stresses are high, with corrosion as a contributing factor. Historical data showed ML #9 tension had decreased significantly in March 2022, with low tension alarms noted in September 2022. The remaining 3 mooring lines on the Port Column were inspected and found in good condition, allowing continued manned operations.
recommendations: The BSEE New Orleans District has no recommendations for the Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Structural Damage/Injury - Mobile 916 Platform AP

event.top_event: Loss of Control During Manual Handling

event.summary: On 22 November 2023 at approximately 1125 hours, a contract construction worker with Burner Fire Control was guiding an eight-foot section of two-inch diameter airline piping being lowered from an elevated pipe rack to the lower deck via rope on Cox Operating's Mobile 916 Platform AP. During the lowering operation, the pipe shifted causing the injured person's right index finger to be pinched between the piping and an I-beam support. The worker was wearing leather impact gloves at the time. The IP was evacuated and diagnosed with a fractured right index finger, resulting in a Loss Time Accident of greater than three days (4-6 weeks recovery).
recommendations: No recommendations issued by BSEE New Orleans District

source.title: Structural Damage - Crane Lifting Incident

context.region: Gulf of America, Main Pass Block 153, Platform B

actions_taken: Stop Work Authority (SWA) invoked
Area secured with wooden boards over damaged grating
Meeting conducted with all personnel involved
Repair materials shipped to location
Fiberbond pipe replaced
ESFWP repaired
Grating repaired with permanent steel covering
ESFWP successfully installed on 04 May 2025
event.summary: On 03 May 2025 at 0830 hours, during a blind lift operation to install an Electric Submersible Fire Water Pump (ESFWP) into a caisson below the top deck, a flange attached to Fiberbond pipe contacted an I-Beam. This contact caused the piping to separate at the flange, resulting in the ESFWP and 25 feet of attached pipe falling 4 feet to the deck below. The incident caused minor damage to deck grating, Fiberbond pipe, and the ESFWP valued at $1,792. No injuries or pollution occurred. The incident was attributed to inadequate hazard identification, failure to use tag lines, and poor communication with multiple personnel giving conflicting instructions to the crane operator during the blind lift.
recommendations: Issue a Safety Alert regarding the incident
Provide and discuss more thorough JSA to identify hazards while performing operations including blind lifts
Utilize extra personnel if needed and designate just one single source of communication with the Crane Operator
Implement better communication techniques for more efficient and safe operations
Designate two signalmen during any blind lifts to provide full coverage when identifying hazards, with only one in direct contact with crane operator
Provide methods of keeping personnel away from lifts being made until loads are secured
Use tag lines to control loads and prevent personnel from being too close to suspended loads

hazards.name: Suspended Load - Heavy Equipment (ESFWP with piping)

threats.name: Load contact with structural obstruction (I-Beam)
Loss of load control during blind lift
Pipe flange separation under load

consequences.name: Personnel injury or fatality from falling equipment

controls.name: Job Safety Analysis (JSA)
controls.barrier_role: Identify hazards before work begins
controls.lod_basis: Pre-work planning and hazard identification

supporting_text: Hazards were not properly identified before or during the blind lift and were not discussed with the personnel involved in the operations
With proper planning, a more thorough evaluation of the area could have been conducted. This evaluation could have identified the I-beam as a hazard
GOM Shelf has stated that in the future, they will provide and discuss a more thorough JSA to identify hazards while performing operations including blind lifts

controls.name: Tag lines for load control
controls.barrier_role: Maintain control and stability of suspended load
controls.lod_basis: Physical control of load during lifting operations

supporting_text: The investigation also identified that personnel did not utilize tag lines or any other means of stabilizing the load as it was being lowered into the caisson
Instead, personnel used their hands to attempt to control the load once it was in reach
Personnel did not utilize tag lines to assist in lowering the lift or raising/stabilizing the lift. This allowed the lift to become off-centered and caused the pipe flange to contact the I-beam
Operators were not instructed to utilize tag lines failed to use tag lines or other means necessary to stabilize the lift that was being made

controls.name: Single designated signalman communication protocol
controls.barrier_role: Ensure clear and unambiguous crane operator instructions
controls.lod_basis: Operational communication and coordination

supporting_text: Both the Operator with the radio on lower deck, and the Signalman on the deck where the lift was being performed, were giving the Crane Operator instructions at the time of the incident, causing confusion that contributed the incident
This took the Crane Operator's attention off the Signalman providing hand signals on the top deck during the lift
Personnel involved in the operation failed to identify a single source of communication from the Signalman to the Crane Operator
Failure to designate one single source of communication to the crane operator during the lift

controls.name: Dual signalman coverage for blind lifts
controls.barrier_role: Provide visibility of all hazards during blind lift operations
controls.lod_basis: Enhanced monitoring and hazard detection

supporting_text: While there was a signalman on the top deck in view of the Crane Operator, there was a failure to provide an additional signalman on the lower deck to identify any possible hazards or obstructions on the bottom side of the top deck where the I-beam was located
Having a signalman on the lower deck could have prevented the incident
In addition, there will be two designated signalmen during any blind lifts to provide full coverage when identifying hazards

controls.name: Pre-job safety meeting and hazard briefing
controls.barrier_role: Ensure all personnel understand hazards and safety processes
controls.lod_basis: Pre-work communication and training

supporting_text: Supervision: No or inadequate pre-job safety and operation meeting- Supervision failed to account for all safety processes that should have been put in place and discussed with personnel during pre-job meetings such as the use of tag lines and establishing proper communication methods during the operation

controls.name: Crane operator visual monitoring
controls.barrier_role: Direct observation of load and hazards during lift
controls.lod_basis: Real-time operational monitoring

supporting_text: Due to the caisson location being below the top deck where the crane was located, the lift was considered a blind lift as the Crane Operator was unable to see the area in which the load was being placed

The Signalman then tried to push on the lift to assist in centering the load, but he was unable to move it. Once he realized he couldn't reposition the load, he tried to signal the Crane Operator to stop lifting the load. Before the lift was able to be stopped, the Fiberbond pipe sections separated at the flange
The Crane Operator stated that he noticed the load jerk as the piping parted

controls.name: Signalman hazard monitoring and intervention
controls.barrier_role: Detect and respond to load hazards during lift
controls.lod_basis: Secondary monitoring and intervention capability

supporting_text: The Signalman on the top deck noticed that the load had become off-center. The Signalman noticed that the flange that was connecting the fiber bond piping was about 1 foot away from an I-beam

The Signalman then looked down to the working area near the caisson to see the progress of the operators handling the sleeve and ESFWP. When the Signalman turned his attention back to the pipe flange, he noticed the flange had become hung up on the I-beam

The Signalman then tried to push on the lift to assist in centering the load, but he was unable to move it. Once he realized he couldn't reposition the load, he tried to signal the Crane Operator to stop lifting the load. Before the lift was able to be stopped, the Fiberbond pipe sections separated

controls.barrier_role: Halt operations after incident to prevent escalation
controls.lod_basis: Post-incident response and recovery

supporting_text: The crew then called an all stop of operations by utilizing Stop Work Authority (SWA)

The operators and additional contractors on the platform relocated to the platform galley where they conducted a meeting with all individuals involved in the operation to discuss the incident that had just occurred

controls.name: Immediate area securing and hazard mitigation
controls.barrier_role: Prevent secondary incidents from damaged equipment
controls.lod_basis: Post-incident physical controls

supporting_text: Once the area was clear of any other safety concerns, the operators used the platform crane to remove the ESFWP from the grating
The operators immediately used wooden boards to cover the bent grating, preventing an open hole hazard in the working area

controls.name: Personnel exclusion zone during lifting
controls.barrier_role: Keep personnel away from suspended loads
controls.lod_basis: Procedural protection of personnel

supporting_text: At the time of the piping separating, personnel were using their hands to guide the ESFWP into place and were in very close proximity to the falling equipment
Proper tag line use would have also prevented personnel from having to be so close to the ESFWP as it was being lowered, raised and repositioned
In the future, more attention should be given to providing methods of keeping personnel away from the lift being made. Personnel should keep a safe distance from the load until secured

Supervision: Inattention to worker safety- As personnel were not instructed to use taglines to guide the ESFWP into place, personnel had to reposition the load by hand, putting themselves into harm's way

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - MP 270 Platform B Glycol Burn Incident

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Main Pass Block 270

actions_taken: IP evacuated via helicopter to onshore heliport at 1645 hours
IP transported to Plaquemines Medical Center in Port Sulphur, LA
Burns scrubbed and cleaned at medical facility

event.summary: On 3 July 2023 at approximately 1545 hours, an 'A' Operator employed by Island Operating Company was testing the Level Safety High/Low (LSHL) on the Glycol Reboiler at Main Pass 270 Platform B when a blockage in the bridle occurred. As the IP cleared the obstruction, heated Triethylene Glycol (350°F) drained out of the bridle and splashed onto the IP, resulting in severe 2nd degree burns to approximately 27% of the body (abdomen, arms, and side). The IP was wearing PPE adequate for ambient temperature liquids but not suitable for 350°F glycol. The IP followed proper testing procedures, but the JSA overlooked the thermal hazard of hot glycol splash.
recommendations: Ensure proper PPE is worn in accordance with MSDS for Triethylene Glycol and protection from thermal risk of hot liquids
Improve JSA to identify thermal hazards and potential for blocked or plugged equipment
Raise awareness of hazards personnel could be exposed to when working with hot liquids and chemicals

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - MP 311 B Platform Pressure Release Incident

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, Main Pass Block 311

actions_taken: Platform immediately shut in
Emergency Shutdown (ESD) stations activated
Production casing valves closed to isolate pressure
Injured personnel evacuated by Air-Med helicopter
Medical attention provided on-site and at University Medical Center
SCADA sensing lines removed and replaced with manual pressure monitoring
New pressure gauges and needle valves installed on all well casings
Leaking downhole plugs replaced
event.summary: On March 12, 2023, at 1633 hours, two Louisiana Safety Systems (LSS) technicians were injured on MP 311 B platform while working on well QAY B-18ST's production casing valves. A 1-inch stainless steel gas lift injection tubing rated at approximately 3100 psi ruptured due to 4330 psi of unexpected trapped pressure. One technician (IP #1) was knocked off a 4-foot aluminum stand and sustained serious injuries requiring helicopter evacuation. The second technician (IP #2) was knocked backwards by the force of escaping gas. The incident resulted from multiple failures: operators failed to monitor casing pressure, failed to perform required casing diagnostics, the facility was not built to approved drawings with tubing under-rated for actual pressures, and no pre-job hazard walkthrough was conducted. Workers were unaware of the 4330 psi pressure on the casing, believing it to be zero based on inaccurate SCADA readings from an isolated sensing line.
recommendations: Generate Safety Alert emphasizing the importance of accurate readings with regards to critical pressure data
Operators of dry trees on gas lift should ensure that their tubing and valves are rated per their approved drawings
Physically verify casing pressures rather than relying solely on SCADA systems
Conduct pre-job hazard walkthroughs to identify potential hazards
Perform casing diagnostics at required intervals
Ensure facility installations match approved drawings

SCADA system inaccurate - sensing line isolated
facility not built to approved drawings
go figure it out, do your job

source.title: Nitrogen Bottle Explosion - Main Pass 42 Delta Platform

context.region: Gulf of America, Main Pass Block 42

actions_taken: BSEE notified by phone and email at 1611 hours on 27 April 2025
Incident report submitted to BSEE eWell Incident Reporting System on 06 May 2025
Seven bottles recovered from top deck and shipped to shore
Cantium required all nitrogen cylinders on their platforms across the Gulf to be inspected
event.summary: On 27 April 2025 at 1520 hours, a nitrogen bottle rack containing 12 bottles (300 cubic feet each) exploded on the top deck of Main Pass 42 Delta platform. One corroded nitrogen bottle ruptured, causing a chain reaction that compromised the aluminum rack and sent bottles flying across the platform. Four bottles went overboard into the Gulf, seven were scattered on deck, and one remained in the damaged rack. No personnel were injured despite being in the vicinity. The bottles were daisy-chained together with 1/4 inch stainless steel tubing, which caused the cascade failure. Investigation revealed the bottles were at least 1 year overdue for inspection.

threats.name: Corrosion of nitrogen bottle
Inadequate inspection and maintenance
Daisy-chain configuration enabling cascade failure

controls.barrier_role: Detect and prevent corrosion-related failures
controls.lod_basis: Routine inspection program to identify equipment degradation

supporting_text: Cantium personnel stated that the 12 nitrogen bottles involved the incident were at least 1 year overdue for inspection
Had the bottle been properly inspected, the corrosion may have been noticed before the bottle had a chance to rupture
there was no maintenance/inspection program to require routine inspection of the nitrogen bottles being used offshore

controls.name: Hazard analysis for nitrogen bottle storage configuration
controls.barrier_role: Identify and mitigate risks of daisy-chain configuration

actions_taken: Facility shut down for approximately eight months

event.summary: On May 30, 2024, molten sodium hydroxide and sodium nitrate erupted from an oxidizing salt bath when a part being processed exploded at the TS USA facility in Chattanooga, Tennessee. Water was trapped in the hollow part which rapidly expanded upon contacting the molten material resulting in the explosion. One employee was fatally injured. $1.3 million in property damage was reported, and the facility was shut down for approximately eight months.
recommendations: Implement physical, protective barriers around molten salt baths
Develop comprehensive safety management system including hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, and incident investigation programs
Develop Knowledge Management program for sharing information throughout organization
Develop Corporate Governance program with regular audits and tracking of corrective actions

source.title: Compressor Piston Failure and Fire - Arena Offshore SM 128 B

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - South Marsh Island Block 128

actions_taken: Night operator activated fire alarm and ESD
Personnel alerted door-to-door
Fire extinguished using firewater hose and 2 (30 lb.) dry chemical extinguishers
Rotating Equipment Specialist investigated on January 17, 2024
Instrumentation and Electrical Contractor tested vibration switches on January 18, 2024
In-line desiccant dryer ordered for pneumatic supply inlets
event.summary: On January 16, 2024, at approximately 0252 hours, the C1 compressor experienced a piston failure at Arena Offshore SM 128 B Facility. The piston rod penetrated the housing, releasing gas that ignited. The night operator discovered the fire, activated the fire alarm and ESD, and alerted personnel. Operators extinguished the fire using a firewater hose and dry chemical extinguishers. Investigation revealed the piston detached from the piston rod due to a loosened nut, causing connecting rod bolts to break and the piston rod to contact the cylinder head. The vibration switch tripped but failed to shut down the compressor due to frozen moisture in the output line caused by 17°F temperatures. No injuries occurred. The compressor is scheduled for rebuild.
recommendations: Install in-line desiccant dryer to pneumatic supply inlets of compressor control panel to prevent condensation formation in tubing

scarring on piston indicating poor maintenance

source.title: Fire Incident During Hot Work Operations - SM 130 A Facility

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - South Marsh Island Block 130

event.summary: On February 4, 2023, at approximately 1405 hours, a small fire occurred on the thief hatch of the ABJ-310 Dry Oil Tank during welding and cutting operations to install a PAT-300 Water Injection Pump. Sparks from cutting operations ignited hydrocarbon vapors venting from the thief hatch. Fire-retardant blankets failed to provide adequate protection. The fire was extinguished with no damage to equipment or injuries to personnel. Investigation revealed multiple failures including inadequate gas monitoring, improper lockout/tagout procedures, insufficient fire protection barriers, and failure to implement previously identified mitigations.

the blankets were not located in a way that protected the thief hatch

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Talos ERT LLC OCS-G02280 SM 130 B Facility Fire

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - South Marsh Island Block 130

event.incident_type: Fire and Explosion from Pipeline Failure
actions_taken: Emergency Shut Down (ESD) activated
Instructions given to remaining platforms in SM 130 field to shut in
Non-essential personnel mustered across bridge to SM 130 D facility
Fire hose used to soak smoldering boards under wet oil tank
Four 30 lb. dry chemical fire extinguishers used to extinguish lifesaving equipment and other items
event.summary: On December 15, 2023, at approximately 0520 hours, an explosion and fire occurred on the Talos ERT LLC OCS-G02280, South Marsh Island 130 B Facility. A 3-foot section of an 8-inch bi-directional gas pipeline (Segment 5114) containing 1220 psi failed due to severe external corrosion of a flange. The resulting fire reached approximately 80 feet high from below the +10 level to the production deck. The flame lasted 5-7 minutes before gas pressure bled down. There was damage to life saving equipment, wiring, and minor structural damage near the +10 level. No injuries occurred. High winds (28 mph) blew the flame away from the platform, potentially preventing more severe damage. Investigation revealed the flange failed due to severe OD corrosion driven by high chlorine concentrations (12,000 ppm) in an oxygen-containing environment, with inadequate coating maintenance and incomplete mechanical integrity inspections.

source.title: BSEE Accident Investigation Report - SM Block 281C Platform Well C-11 Incident

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - South Marsh Island Block 281

actions_taken: All well operations stopped immediately
Contractors evacuated to Lift Boat New Orleans
Stop Work Authority called
B&B Wellhead Services technician mobilized
Casing beams and casing jack rigged up
Well C-11 tree pulled up 3 inches with casing jack
5,000 psi ball valve installed on 9.625-inch production casing
500-foot cement balance plug set from 11,100 feet to 10,600 feet
Permanent well abandonment completed on 29 September 2023
event.summary: On 9 September 2023, during well abandonment operations on Well C-28 at Apache Corporation's SM Block 281C platform, the 13.375-inch casing on adjacent Well C-11 dropped approximately 3 feet due to severe corrosion failure. The drop sheared off the valve for the 13.375-inch casing completely and partially sheared the valve for the 9.625-inch production casing, releasing 704 psi of gas lift pressure into the atmosphere. The incident was caused by complete loss of the 26-inch conductor casing due to corrosion, which exposed the 13.375-inch surface casing to severe corrosion, ultimately causing it to collapse. Platform grating and decking around Well C-11 were damaged. No injuries or pollution were reported. Apache failed to immediately notify BSEE as required by regulations.
recommendations: Apache Corporation shall submit letter of explanation to BSEE Lafayette District Manager
Apache Corporation shall submit plans to prevent future incidents of this nature
Apache Corporation shall notify BSEE District Office immediately for any incidents involving wellhead falling, structural damage and release of uncontrolled hydrocarbons

source.title: Crane Boom Structural Damage - SM 130 B Facility

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - South Marsh Island Block 130

actions_taken: Crane boom set in boom rest

event.summary: On February 25, 2024, at approximately 0930 hours, a crane boom was damaged while attempting to raise the elevation of an I-beam approximately 1-inch on the Talos ERT LLC SM 130 B Facility. After unsuccessful attempts with come along winches, the contract construction crew attached the main line of the crane to the I-beam and applied tension up to 30,000 lbs. The crane boom was damaged at the heel section and a boom lattice after the load rating was exceeded. The crane was at a 55-degree angle with a maximum capacity of 21,500 lbs. There were no injuries and estimated repair cost is $400,000.
recommendations: Ensure crane operators monitor weight indicators while having knowledge of maximum capacity of boom angle
Do not connect cranes to or use to lift fixed objects
Ensure JSEA discusses all hazards involved with planned operations
Conduct stop work when original plan changes or is unsuccessful
Adhere to API RP 2D standards as referenced in 30 CFR 250.198

threats.name: Exceeding crane load rating
Using crane to lift fixed object
Inadequate hazard identification in JSEA
Failure to stop work when plan changes

consequences.name: Potential personnel injury from boom failure
