source.title: Crane Boom Collapse - Talos ERT LLC OCS-G02280 South Marsh Island 130 B Facility

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - South Marsh Island Block 130

actions_taken: BSEE onsite investigation conducted on May 15, 2023
Four samples of failed boom cable sent to Core Lifting for analysis and testing on July 20, 2023
Break tests conducted on 12-foot sections of failed cable
Bridle assembly inspected by Sparrows for non-biased assessment
Boom cable from same spool tested on another Talos crane and passed
Sheaves visually inspected and bridle replaced
event.summary: On May 12, 2023, at approximately 1605 hours, a crane boom collapse occurred on the Talos ERT LLC OCS-G02280 South Marsh Island 130 B Facility. While attempting to lower a basket of grating weighing approximately 11,000 lbs to the top deck using a four-part load line, the boom cable failed when the grating rack was approximately 6 ft from the top deck and the boom angle was at 76 degrees. The boom collapsed and landed on the top deck, causing approximately $330,000 in damage to the deck and production equipment and $370,000 in crane damage. There were no injuries to personnel. Analysis by Core Lifting determined the boom cable failed due to fatigue from numerous cycles through the bridle sheaves, evidenced by numerous short pieces of wire embedded in the cable with fatigue fractures at both ends. The crane had accumulated 124 hours of run time since the boom cable was installed on May 28, 2021.
recommendations: Replace wire rope when dimension reaches nominal wire rope size, not reduction size as per API RP 2D
Include additional wire rope micrometer evaluations of boom cable on all Talos operated cranes during quarterly and annual inspection schedules, with readings taken in areas of high rotation and wear
Conduct boom cable replacement at maximum of 100 hours or within one year on SMI-130B crane to determine adequate wire rope replacement criteria and crane function
Search for alternative lubrication that will provide ample penetration to cable core
key_phrases: confined area of boom cable through bridle sheaves
wire rope evaluations failed to recognize fatigue
Lubriplate lubrication failed to penetrate core

threats.name: Wire Rope Fatigue from Cyclic Loading
Inadequate Lubrication Penetration
Repetitive High Boom Angle Operations

The .645 caliper diameter of the boom cable recorded on the annual inspections between installation and the cable failure had not changed.
Also, there were no discrepancies found with the boom cable on the last annual crane inspection.
Equipment Failure – Inadequate preventative maintenance: wire rope evaluations failed to recognize the fatigue occurring in the confined area of the boom cable.

event.summary: On September 21, 2024, at approximately 1630 hours, a contract construction supervisor injured his right eye while familiarizing himself with a banding tool for heliport skirting repairs on the SM 160 A Facility. event.summary: On 18 July 2025 at 0730 hours, the Motor Vessel Marc C allided with South Pass 27 #5 platform during platform surveying operations for decommissioning. The vessel captain set course to West Delta field approximately 3 minutes after leaving East Bay field without properly clearing all structures. The captain was distracted by computer work and failed to use the electronic navigation chart system, violating company safe navigation policy. The allision caused damage to both the platform structure and the starboard bow of the vessel. No injuries or pollution occurred.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations should consider issuing a Safety Alert regarding the incident
GOL to share safety alert with fleet for maneuvering close to platforms/structures and safe navigation
GOL to hold review of navigation policy with each vessel of entire fleet

event.summary: On 21 September 2023 at 0745 hours, production operators discovered an external leak on the production casing (B casing) of Well #98 on South Pass 28 13(V) jacket. Gas and oil were escaping through a hole in the side of the casing, creating a hydrocarbon sheen in Gulf waters. Despite immediately shutting in the well and closing the SCSSV, hydrocarbons continued to escape. Multiple intervention attempts were made over 8 days before a bridge plug was successfully set on 29 September, with the leak stopping on 30 September at 0132 hours. Total spill was estimated at 65.7 gallons of oil. The incident was attributed to equipment failure due to inadequate preventive maintenance and severe corrosion in an extremely harsh shallow saltwater environment.

notes.additional_notes: Incident involved multiple barrier failures due to inadequate maintenance in harsh environment. Production personnel demonstrated positive situational awareness by detecting the leak during routine field travel. However, organizational failures in maintenance programs and regulatory compliance (LOTO, equipment maintenance, access ladder) contributed significantly. Three INCs issued: E-100 for pollution, G-111 C for equipment maintenance failure, G-111 W for access ladder maintenance. Total estimated damage $260,723. Environmental impact: 65.7 gallons oil spilled, 4-mile sheen, no recovery due to sea conditions.

source.title: Structural Damage - Mechanical Casing Cutter Bowl Separation Incident

context.region: Gulf of America, South Pass Block 49, Lease G02177

event.top_event: Loss of Containment of Mechanical Energy
actions_taken: Immediate first aid administered to control bleeding
Severed finger retrieved for possible reattachment
IP evacuated via Motor Vessel to A platform
Medic stabilized injury and preserved severed tissue
IP airlifted via helicopter to Venice, LA
Ground ambulance transport to University Medical Center New Orleans
Safety standdown conducted on platform
All operations halted for the day
Crew subsequently procured slings for future operations
event.summary: On July 30, 2025, during plug and abandonment operations on Well C005 at the South Pass 49 C platform, a Supreme Services crew was laying down a 12-inch mechanical casing cutter into a shipping basket. While guiding the tool, the outermost slip bowl (approximately 250 pounds) unexpectedly separated due to grease lock and slid down the tool. A Supreme operator's left hand was caught between the bowl and tool, resulting in traumatic amputation of one finger and crush injuries to two others, which were later permanently amputated. Investigation revealed that the operator's no hands policy was not effectively communicated or enforced, hands-free tools were not provided, no task-specific risk assessment was conducted, and the hazard of bowl separation was not identified.
recommendations: Implement and enforce no-hands policy with documented training for all crew members
Provide hands-free tools (push poles, mechanical handling aids) for all lifting operations
Implement permit process for manual tool handling
Conduct task-specific pre-job safety meetings and risk assessments
Mechanically restrain heavy components before changing tool orientation
Improve hazard recognition training for stored mechanical energy
Implement stop work authority training and enforcement

hazards.name: Stored Mechanical Energy in Casing Cutter Assembly

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - South Pass 62 C Platform Gas Release

context.region: Gulf of America, South Pass Block 62

actions_taken: Platform manually shut in after gas release confirmed

event.summary: On 03 November 2025 at 1205 hours, a BSEE Inspector conducting an annual production inspection on South Pass 62 C platform noticed suspected gas fumes coming from a corroded area of an 8-inch gas vent line. Platform operators confirmed the gas release using a portable gas detector. The gas was leaking from the corroded pipe and blowing under the wet and dry oil tanks. The platform was manually shut in. The gas release was not detected by the platform safety system and did not initiate any alarms. The corroded section of piping had not been identified by API Level 1 surveys or platform operators. No injuries or pollution occurred. The platform remained shut in until repairs were completed on 09 November 2025.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations should consider issuing a Safety Alert regarding the incident
Further attention should be given to identifying corrosion issues on all platform process piping
Operator should consider establishing routine corrosion inspections in addition to the Level 1 surveys
Additional efforts in identifying corrosion on process piping could prevent future gas releases and limit the possibility of explosion hazards

operators were unaware of the on-going hazard
more severe incident could have occurred if an ignition source had been introduced

event.summary: On 21 September 2023 at approximately 1505 hours, an injury occurred on South Pass Block 83 Platform A during plug and abandonment operations. A three-person crew was reinstalling a 12-inch PIG launcher cap onto gas pipeline PIG launcher KZZ-602 after pipeline flushing operations. The lever arm assembly that assists in positioning the cap had become damaged during removal, forcing the crew to manually lift the cap. The crew mistakenly believed the cap was securely threaded and lessened their hold, causing it to fall. The sharp edge of the lever arm shaft penetrated the injured person's cut-resistant gloves, causing a laceration to the right hand. The IP was evacuated by helicopter and treated with eleven sutures at an onshore medical facility.

event.summary: On January 31, 2023, during temporary abandonment operations of the E-4 well at Ship Shoal 224 E platform, an electric line casing cutter was fired at 120 feet below mud line. Trapped pressure in the annulus between the 10-3/4 inch and 7-5/8 inch casing was released when the casing was cut below the subsea wellhead tieback system. The pressure release ejected the tool string from the well, damaging grating on the cellar and wellbay decks. No injuries occurred. The crew was unaware that the well did not communicate above or below the subsea tieback system, and no wireline pressure control equipment was used because the surface wellhead had been removed in 2007.
recommendations: Install slip-on surface wellhead on all wells with subsea wellhead systems
Update standard operating procedures to include pressure control equipment before perforating untested annuli

source.title: Fire Incident at Ship Shoal Block 80 Platform A

context.region: Gulf of America, Ship Shoal Block 80

actions_taken: Facility immediately shut-in
Remaining flame extinguished with wheeled fire extinguisher

event.summary: On March 7, 2025, at 0815 hours, a flash fire occurred at W&T Offshore's Ship Shoal Block 80 Platform A while attempting to bring Pipeline Pump #2 online. When the electrician opened the start valve to supply fuel gas to the pump's starter, a backfire occurred followed by a flash fire. Investigation revealed an extremely loose fitting on the vent exhaust piping from the fuel gas starter allowed gas to seep out and accumulate. The backfire ignited the accumulated gas, causing a flash fire that injured a mechanic and electrician with burns to their heads and hands. Neither worker was wearing proper PPE (gloves). Wind conditions (25-30 knots from the south) pushed flames into the mechanic positioned on the northern side of the pump, causing more severe injuries. Both were evacuated and treated at burn unit, with the electrician returning to work April 9, 2025.
recommendations: When using fuel gas to start prime movers, always ensure the starter exhaust gas is vented to a safe location
Review gas engine startup procedures to include equipment checks verifying proper installation of components
Utilize gas detectors when performing startup procedures on engines with gas as a fuel source and/or as a pneumatic supply for starters
Conduct mandatory checks on engines with gas as a fuel source and/or as a pneumatic supply for starters to ensure proper installation of starter exhaust piping
Share findings at Field Lead Meeting
Conduct blitzes/audits on gas-operated equipment on all facilities to verify that all flexible hoses are replaced with hard piping
Begin routine checks on all fittings associated with starter gas
Stress the importance of wearing all required PPE
Generate safety alert to discuss the importance of inspecting equipment prior to start up

source.title: Crane Load Block Failure - ST-229 Platform A

context.region: Gulf of America, South Timbalier Area Block 229, Lease OCS-G13938

event.incident_type: Crane load block failure with dropped object
actions_taken: Crane immediately secured and locked out
Injured person evacuated to Port of Fourchon via MV Force
IP transported to Occupational Medicine Services in Houma, Louisiana
Load block and ejected sheave shipped to crane contractor maintenance facility for RCA
BSEE onsite investigation conducted May 12, 2025
Crane contractor revised Primary Inspection Checklist and Block and Hook Inspection Form
Safety alerts issued by W&T and crane contractor
Enhanced maintenance protocols implemented requiring flushing and verification of lubrication pathways
Photographic documentation added to annual inspections
event.summary: On May 9, 2025, during crane operations to lower a JSA document to a supply vessel at platform ST-229A, a sheave bearing failure in the crane load block caused a catastrophic mechanical failure. An internal debris restriction in the sheave pin's lubrication passage prevented adequate grease from reaching the bearings. One bearing failed, generating excessive rotational force that sheared the anti-rotation dowel pin. This allowed the sheave pin and spiral retainers to rotate freely, causing them to unwind and dislodge. The wire rope (135 ft, 78.3 lbs) fell onto the aft deck of the MV Force, followed by the load block (falling 65 ft, 1,235 lbs). The ejected sheave (32 lbs) was slung upward approximately 100 feet before landing on a grocery box on the vessel deck. A deckhand, standing approximately 20 feet away, sustained a lumbar muscle strain while evading the falling components. All three objects possessed fatal potential energy. The incident was classified as a near-miss and first aid case. The IP was released to full duty but did not return to work. Root cause analysis confirmed inadequate lubrication due to internal obstruction. Contributing factors included failure to follow safe work practice of lowering loads to minimum safe height before swinging over vessels, and inadequate operator awareness of early mechanical distress indicators.
recommendations: BSEE Houma District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations issue a Safety Alert

hazards.name: Mechanical energy in rotating crane components

threats.name: Inadequate lubrication to load block sheave bearing
Internal debris obstruction in lubrication passage
Bearing failure generating excessive rotational force
Shearing of anti-rotation dowel pin
Failure to detect early mechanical distress indicators
Suspended load maintained at excessive height over vessel

consequences.name: Personnel injury from evading dropped objects
Potential fatality from dropped load block (226,047.59 joules impact energy)
Potential fatality from dropped wire rope (14,331.60 joules impact energy)
Potential fatality from ejected sheave (5,857.10 joules impact energy)
Equipment damage to crane assembly and vessel deck

controls.name: Crane Pre-Use Inspection
controls.barrier_role: Detection of mechanical degradation before operations
controls.lod_basis: Frontline operational check performed by crane operator before each use

supporting_text: Prior to the work beginning, the Job Safety Analysis (JSA) and Crane Pre-Use Inspections were completed.

Operators did not recognize or act upon potential audible, visual, or tactile distress indicators (e.g., block rocking, grinding/popping, reduced wire-rope tension) that should have triggered an immediate out-of-service action and inspection.
The crane contractor emphasized the importance of thorough Crane Pre-Use Inspections by crane operators, including visual checks of all load block pins, retainers, and hardware.

controls.name: Lubrication of load block sheave bearings during maintenance
controls.barrier_role: Prevent bearing failure through adequate lubrication
controls.lod_basis: Routine maintenance activity to maintain equipment integrity

supporting_text: It was confirmed that lubrication is required during annual, quarterly, and monthly inspections, as noted in Section III of the crane contractor's Primary Inspection Checklist.

The presence of fresh grease found during both the BSEE IF Investigation and the teardown of the load block at the crane contractor maintenance facility confirmed that standard greasing procedures were performed properly prior to the incident.

Debris buildup discovered in the internal lubrication passage between the 90-degree transition and the passage outlet, prevented grease lubricant from reaching the pin and bearing, leading to failure of one of the three sheave bearings.

Equipment Failure – Inadequate lubrication to component (internal obstruction)- An internal debris restriction in the sheave pin's lubrication passage prevented grease from reaching the sheave bearings.

controls.name: Inspection of internal lubrication passages
controls.barrier_role: Detect internal obstructions preventing lubrication flow
controls.lod_basis: Verification and oversight activity beyond routine maintenance

supporting_text: It was concluded that because the internal lubrication passages were found obstructed beyond the visible and serviceable points, the restriction could not have been identified without full disassembly.

Management Systems: Inadequate documentation/procedural specificity- Prior to post-incident revisions, inspection/maintenance documentation did not explicitly require verification of internal lubrication flow paths or detailed retainer condition checks, which reduced the chance of discovering internal degradation short of disassembly.

The crane contractor's Technicians are now required to flush and verify all lubrication pathways during servicing, with any irregular grease pressure or incomplete return flow prompting additional internal inspections.

controls.name: Anti-rotation dowel pin
controls.barrier_role: Prevent sheave pin rotation and retainer dislodgement
controls.lod_basis: Passive engineered safeguard designed into load block assembly

supporting_text: The dowel that prevented sheave pin rotation sheared due to excessive rotational force, allowing the pin and its spiral retainers to rotate freely within the frame.
Equipment Failure – Component failure (sheared dowel pin- anti-rotation/safeguard feature)- The excessive rotational force sheared the dowel designed to prevent sheave pin rotation.
The Crane Mechanic described the event as an extremely rare mechanical failure, citing that sheave dowel pins are difficult to dislodge.

controls.name: Spiral retainers on sheave pin
controls.barrier_role: Retain sheave pin in seated position within load block frame
controls.lod_basis: Passive engineered component designed to prevent pin migration

supporting_text: Friction against the retainer faces caused them to unwind and dislodge from the pin's machined grooves, allowing the sheave pin to migrate from its seated position and work its way out of the block.
With the dowel compromised, the pin and spiral retainers rotated; friction unwound a retainer and dislodged from its groove, the pin backed out, leading to ejection of a sheave.

controls.name: Safe work practice: Lower loads to minimum safe height before swinging over vessel
controls.barrier_role: Minimize consequence severity by reducing drop height and impact energy
controls.lod_basis: Frontline operational practice to reduce exposure

supporting_text: When lowering loads to a MV, lower loads to their lowest and safest height above the water and just high enough to clear any obstructions before swinging the load from above the water to its desired destination on the back deck of the MV. The Crane Operator and Rigger stated that they always follow this safe work practice while transferring loads.

They acknowledged that the practice minimizes potential severity before proceeding to swing a load over a MV and agreed that the Load Block should never have existed 65 feet above the deck of the boat. However, the Crane Operator admitted he had never considered this practice when simply lowering a JSA to the MV for review.

Management Systems – Inadequate hazard analysis- Unsafe Work Practice increasing consequence severity- Maintaining the load block at approximately 65 ft over the MV during positioning increased potential consequences once failure occurred. Even though it did not cause the mechanical failure, the injury could have been prevented by an adequate hazard analysis that identified the hazard of the suspended load at height and mitigation of lowering the load to its safest and lowest point before swinging over the boat.

controls.name: Personnel positioning and exclusion zone during crane operations
controls.barrier_role: Prevent personnel from being in drop zone of suspended loads
controls.lod_basis: Frontline operational practice to prevent exposure

supporting_text: The Crane Operator mentions in the report that the Deckhand (IP) was on the back deck of the boat but was not directly under the load and had time to move away before the load block hit the deck.
The Crane Operator estimated that the Deckhand (IP) was standing approximately 20 feet away when the wire rope began to pay out and he began to run away.
According to his description, when the IP saw the wire rope cable fall to the deck, he twisted his back as he ran to get out of the way.

controls.name: Anti-two block system
controls.barrier_role: Prevent over-hoisting and two-blocking condition
controls.lod_basis: Automated engineered safety system

supporting_text: As the load block was lifted high enough to clear the bulwarks of the MV, the anti-two block triggered and disabled the 'line-up' function of the winch.
He mentioned that to utilize the winch to recover the load block and stinger back onto the top deck of the facility, he had to cap off the anti-two block controls.
Hydraulic plumbing associated with the anti-two block was found bent and pulled away from their fixtures.

controls.name: Crane lockout/tagout and out-of-service procedures
controls.barrier_role: Prevent further use of failed equipment and escalation
controls.lod_basis: Post-incident recovery action to prevent recurrence

supporting_text: The crane was immediately secured.
After the incident, the Rigger locked out the controls on the crane and placed an OOS placard on the crane.
BSEE noted that the crane(stenciled as ZZZ-9000)was flagged Out of Service (OOS), and the controls were locked out.

controls.name: Emergency evacuation procedures
controls.barrier_role: Provide timely medical treatment to injured personnel
controls.lod_basis: Emergency response to mitigate injury consequences

supporting_text: The IP was evacuated via the Gulf Offshore Logistics (GOL) motor vessel (MV) 'Force' to the Port of Fourchon and transported to Occupational Medicine Services (OMS) in Houma, Louisiana, for further treatment.
The IP was evacuated via GOL's MV Force to the Port of Fourchon and transported to OMS in Houma, Louisiana, where he received first aid treatment for a lumbar muscle strain and released to full duty.

controls.name: Job Safety Analysis (JSA)
controls.barrier_role: Identify hazards and establish safe work procedures before task execution
controls.lod_basis: Frontline planning activity to identify and control hazards

supporting_text: Prior to the work beginning, the Job Safety Analysis (JSA) and Crane Pre-Use Inspections were completed.
The JSA was placed in a kitchen trash bag and attached to the hook of the stinger from the load block in order for it to be lowered down to the MV for review and signature.

Management Systems – Inadequate hazard analysis- Unsafe Work Practice increasing consequence severity- Maintaining the load block at approximately 65 ft over the MV during positioning increased potential consequences once failure occurred. Even though it did not cause the mechanical failure, the injury could have been prevented by an adequate hazard analysis that identified the hazard of the suspended load at height.

controls.name: Crane maintenance inspection documentation and checklists
controls.barrier_role: Ensure systematic verification of critical components during maintenance
controls.lod_basis: Management system oversight of maintenance quality

supporting_text: Management Systems: Inadequate documentation/procedural specificity- Prior to post-incident revisions, inspection/maintenance documentation did not explicitly require verification of internal lubrication flow paths or detailed retainer condition checks, which reduced the chance of discovering internal degradation short of disassembly.
In response to this incident, the crane contractor revised their Block and Hook Inspection Form to explicitly require verification of 'lubrication points serviced.'

The crane contractor revised its Primary Inspection Checklist and Block and Hook Inspection Form to explicitly require verification of 'lubrication points serviced' and incorporate more detailed evaluations of critical load block components, including specification of retainer types, sheave pins, snap rings, and lubrication functionality.

controls.name: Operator training on early mechanical distress indicators
controls.barrier_role: Enable early detection and intervention before catastrophic failure
controls.lod_basis: Frontline competency to recognize abnormal conditions

supporting_text: Personnel Training: Personnel not trained on equipment used or system operated (awareness depth)- The investigation identified the need to strengthen operator awareness of early mechanical distress signs and responses (later addressed via safety alerts and training). This gap contributed somewhat to the event by reducing the likelihood of early detection and intervention.

W & T and the crane contractor both published internal safety alerts that echoed the same message: moving forward, all crane operators should remain alert to visual, audible, or tactile warning signs such as strange noises, load block tilting or rocking, unusual wire rope slack or tension, or jerky behavior.

The W & T/crane contractor investigation sought to determine whether failure of the load block could have been prevented by detection of early indicators of load block degradation. W & T/crane contractor indicated in their reports that early indicators include increased grease pump resistance, bearing binding, side shifting, popping, or block rocking.

event.summary: On January 29, 2024 at approximately 1745, a fire occurred on the Glycol Reboiler vent line at Cantium LLC facility South Timbalier Block 23 CC. The facility had shut in due to a Level Safety Low on the Glycol Surge Tank. While operators were pumping glycol into the Surge Vessel, a flame was noticed coming from the Pressure Safety Valve vent line for the Glycol Reboiler when the valve relieved pressure. The fire was extinguished using potable water. Investigation revealed that the packing section was not reinstalled properly in the still column after maintenance in October 2023. Without the packing section, the ability to preheat glycol was removed, allowing entrained gases to be released into the Reboiler, causing the PSV to relieve and ignite.

source.title: Little General Store Propane Explosion (Ghent)

event.summary: On January 30, 2007, a propane explosion at the Little General Store in Ghent, West Virginia, killed four people (two propane service technicians and two emergency responders) and injured six others. A junior propane service technician was transferring liquid propane from an existing tank to a newly installed tank when he removed a plug from the existing tank's liquid withdrawal valve, causing liquid propane to spray out. A large vapor cloud formed and expanded into the store. The technician called his supervisor and then 911, but minutes after emergency responders arrived, the explosion occurred. The explosion leveled the store, destroyed a responding ambulance, and damaged nearby vehicles.

source.title: BP America Refinery Explosion - Recommendations Status Change Summary

context.region: Texas City, Texas, USA

actions_taken: API revised API Recommended Practice 521 (6th edition, January 2014)
Added guidance on overfilling vessels as potential hazard (Section 4.4.7)
Added guidance on sizing disposal drums for credible worse-case liquid relief scenarios (Section 5)
Added warnings against atmospheric releases and requirement for inherently safer alternatives (Sections 5.8.7.1 and 5.8.8)
event.summary: On March 23, 2005, a series of explosions and fire occurred at the BP Texas City refinery during the re-starting of an isomerization (ISOM) unit, killing 15 workers, injuring 180, and resulting in substantial economic losses. The event was triggered when a raffinate splitter tower was overfilled during startup. The overfilling caused pressure relief devices to open and dump flammable liquid into a blowdown drum fitted with a stack without a flare. The blowdown drum also overfilled, releasing flammable liquid out of the stack into the surrounding area where it evaporated as it fell to ground. Subsequent ignition of the flammable vapors led to the explosions and fire.
recommendations: Revise API RP 521 to identify overfilling vessels as a potential hazard for evaluation in selecting and designing pressure relief and disposal systems
Address the need to adequately size disposal drums for credible worse-case liquid relief scenarios, based on accurate relief valve and disposal collection piping studies

Warn against the use of atmospheric blowdown drums and stacks attached to collection piping systems that receive flammable discharges from multiple relief valves and urge the use of appropriate inherently safer alternatives such as a flare system

source.title: Public Safety at Oil and Gas Storage Facilities

context.region: United States

event.incident_type: Multiple Fatal Explosions at Unmanned Storage Facilities
actions_taken: CSB initiated investigation in April 2010
API approved Addendum 1 to Recommended Practice 12R1 in December 2017
New Annex J added covering unmanned upstream facility design and safety considerations
event.summary: Between October 2009 and early 2010, three separate fatal explosions occurred at unmanned oil and gas storage tank facilities in Mississippi, Oklahoma, and Texas, killing four people and seriously injuring others. All victims were 25 years or younger. The CSB investigation identified 26 similar incidents between 1983 and 2010 resulting in 44 fatalities and 25 injuries. All incidents involved rural unmanned sites lacking fencing and hazard signage. The CSB found that existing API standards did not adequately address security measures for upstream exploration and production facilities to prevent unauthorized public access.
recommendations: Create new standard or amend existing standards for E&P facilities warning of tampering and ignition source risks
Recommend inherently safer storage tank design features including restrictions on open vents, flame arrestors, pressure vacuum vent valves, floating roofs, vapor recovery systems
Require security measures including full fencing with locked gates, hatch locks on tank manways, barriers on external ladders
Require hazard signs or placards on or near tanks identifying fire and explosion hazards
Recommend new mineral leasing agreements include security and signage requirements

source.title: Honeywell Chemical Incidents

context.region: Baton Rouge, Louisiana, USA

actions_taken: Hospitalization of four plant workers

event.summary: On July 20, 2003, chlorine gas was released from Honeywell's refrigerant manufacturing plant in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, resulting in hospitalization of four workers and requiring nearby residents to shelter in place. Chlorine entered the control room through the HVAC system, forcing employee evacuation before the leak could be stopped, and corroded the process control system rendering it inoperable. Two subsequent incidents occurred: on July 29, 2003, a worker was fatally injured by antimony pentachloride exposure from a gas cylinder release, and on August 13, 2003, two workers were exposed to hydrofluoric acid with one hospitalized. The CSB investigation identified lacking guidance and standards for positive pressure control room design and maintenance in the U.S. chemical industry.
recommendations: Develop guidance on the effective design and maintenance of HVAC systems and other necessary control room components designed to protect employees and equipment in the event of a release of hazardous materials

event.summary: On November 17, 2003, chlorine gas was released from the DPC Enterprises chlorine repackaging facility in Glendale, Arizona. source.title: DuPont Yerkes Fatal Hot Work Explosion

context.region: Buffalo, New York, USA
context.operator: E.I. DuPont de Nemours and Co.

actions_taken: DuPont developed and issued new corporate standard S31F: Hot Work
Comprehensive roll-out package provided to all U.S. sites in August 2012
Training sessions conducted between August and December 2012
Refresher training planned as required by the standard
event.summary: On November 9, 2010, one contract worker was killed and another was injured in an explosion at the DuPont Yerkes facility in Buffalo, New York. Contractors were welding atop a 10,000 gallon slurry tank when hot sparks ignited flammable vinyl fluoride vapor that had accumulated inside the tank, triggering an explosion. The investigation found multiple deficiencies in the hot work permitting process, including incomplete permits, lack of hazard verification, failure to isolate the tank from adjacent in-service tanks via an overflow line, and absence of atmospheric testing for flammable vapor.
recommendations: R1: Develop and enforce corporate-directed policies and procedures requiring all DuPont facilities to audit hot work permitting systems to ensure explosion hazards are identified and mitigated, all forms are completed per corporate policies and industry standards (NFPA 326 and NFPA 51B), and appropriate personnel approve permits

R2: Revise corporate policies to require positive isolation of all process piping or connections to tanks/vessels using closed valves, blind flanges or pancake blanks, and appropriate venting before authorizing hot work
R3: Revise corporate policies to require atmosphere monitoring inside containers for flammable vapor prior to performing welding, cutting, or grinding on container surfaces

R4: Revise corporate policies to require air monitoring for flammable vapor inside containers for the duration of hot work consistent with industry standards (NFPA 326, NFPA 51B), and create policy for determining criteria for continuous or periodic testing

source.title: Technic Vent Collection System Explosion

context.region: Cranston, Rhode Island, USA

actions_taken: Community evacuation
Facility operations interrupted for several weeks
Eighteen employees sent to hospital for medical evaluations
event.summary: On February 7, 2003, an explosion and fire occurred inside a vent collection system at the Technic plating chemicals manufacturing and research facility in Cranston, Rhode Island. The explosion was likely initiated when an employee tapped a small hammer against a duct that sounded blocked. The CSB concluded the explosion resulted from a violent chemical reaction inside the vent collection system, likely caused by either a violent reaction between two incompatible materials or a violent reaction of a shock-sensitive material. One employee was critically injured and eighteen others were sent to the hospital. The surrounding community was evacuated and facility operations were interrupted for several weeks.
recommendations: Update the preliminary steps in the chapter on exhaust system design in the next revision of the Industrial Ventilation Manual, emphasizing the need to evaluate potential incompatibilities between dusts, fumes or vapors that are likely to be intermixed in main header ducts of a ventilation system
Reference appropriate methods for such evaluation, such as the ASTM E 2012-00 standard

ACC responded by revising its Responsible Care Process Safety Code to take an all-hazards approach that comprehensively addresses reactive hazards through hazard identification, evaluation, management of change, inherently safer design, and adequate procedures and training.

event.summary: On November 27, 2019, a dead leg between the Final Fractionator A and a manual isolation valve upstream of an offline pump ruptured at TPC Group Port Neches butadiene unit. event.summary: On August 28, 2016, a nitrous oxide trailer truck exploded at the Airgas manufacturing facility in Cantonment, Florida, killing one employee and heavily damaging the facility. During initial loading operations, a pump manufactured by ACD LLC heated nitrous oxide above its safe operating limits, initiating a decomposition reaction that propagated from the pump into the trailer truck, causing the explosion. The incident was attributed to inadequate warnings in ACD product literature about nitrous oxide decomposition hazards.
recommendations: Modify nitrous oxide pump product literature to include warnings about nitrous oxide decomposition hazards, illustrated by examples from historical incidents, and refer users to this CSB investigation report for additional information

source.title: Caribbean Petroleum Refining Tank Explosion and Fire - Recommendation Status Change Summary

context.region: Bayamon, Puerto Rico

event.incident_type: Tank Overfill with Vapor Cloud Explosion and Fire
actions_taken: CSB issued recommendations to API to revise standards for overfill protection
API published 5th Edition of Standard 2350 with improved technical requirements for AOPS
Fires burned for almost 60 hours before being extinguished
event.summary: On October 23, 2009, while offloading gasoline from the tanker ship Cape Bruny into the CAPECO onshore tank farm, approximately 200,000 gallons of gasoline overflowed from an aboveground storage tank into a secondary containment dike with an open drain. Gasoline sprayed from the tank's roof vents, aerosolized, and formed a large vapor cloud covering approximately 107 acres. The vapor cloud ignited at the wastewater treatment facility, causing a blast that registered 2.9 on the Richter scale, multiple secondary explosions, and fires that burned for almost 60 hours. The incident resulted in significant damage to 17 of 48 petroleum storage tanks, approximately 300 homes and businesses up to 1.25 miles away, three minor injuries offsite, and petroleum contamination of soil, wetlands, and waterways.
recommendations: Revise ANSI/API 2350 to require automatic overfill prevention systems for existing and new facilities at bulk aboveground storage tanks storing gasoline, jet fuel, other fuel mixtures or blendstocks, and other flammable liquids having an NFPA 704 flammability rating of 3 or higher
Ensure overfill prevention systems are physically separated and independent from level control and monitoring systems
Engineer, operate, and maintain systems to achieve appropriate safety integrity level per IEC 61511
Conduct documented risk assessment per CCPS Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures accounting for nearby populations, facility operations, system reliability, and operator monitoring
Proof test systems with sufficient frequency to maintain required safety integrity level
Ensure changes are not subject to grandfathering provisions

source.title: Enterprise Pascagoula Gas Plant Explosion and Fire

context.region: Pascagoula, Mississippi

actions_taken: Site shut down for almost six months
API published First Edition of Standard 668 in November 2018
API Subcommittee on Heat Transfer Equipment revised standard with CSB input
event.summary: On June 27, 2016, a major loss of containment resulted in the release of methane, ethane, propane, and several other hydrocarbons at the Enterprise Products Pascagoula Gas Plant in Pascagoula, Mississippi. The hydrocarbons ignited, initiating a series of fires and explosions, which ultimately shut down the site for almost six months. Two workers were on the night shift when the incident occurred and were uninjured. The CSB determined that the probable cause of this incident was the failure of a brazed aluminum heat exchanger (BAHX) due to thermal fatigue. The absence of a reliable process to ensure the mechanical integrity of the heat exchanger contributed to the catastrophic failure of the equipment.
recommendations: Develop guidance focused on safe operation, maintenance, and repair of BAHX to advance understanding of thermal fatigue hazards
Include information on potential for minor leaks and catastrophic failure from accumulated thermal fatigue
Clarify optimal placement of BAHX temperature and pressure sensors to monitor thermal fatigue impact
Clarify need to safely vent layers blocked off during repair of interpass leaks in all BAHX configurations

source.title: Intercontinental Terminal Company (ITC) Tank Fire

context.region: Deer Park, Texas

actions_taken: Fire suppression efforts for three days
Firefighting foam application
Emergency response to containment wall collapse
event.summary: On March 17, 2019, a loss of containment and fire occurred at the ITC terminal facility in Deer Park, Texas, resulting from seal failure of a pump operating with Tank 80-8, an 80,000 barrel above ground atmospheric storage tank containing naphtha and butane mixture. The fire burned for three days, spreading to all fifteen tanks in the containment area, destroying them all. On March 22, 2019, the containment wall partially collapsed, releasing approximately 500,000 barrels (21 million gallons) of petroleum products, firefighting foam, and water into Tucker Bayou and the Houston Ship Channel. event.summary: On July 27, 2021, three contract workers at the LyondellBasell La Porte Complex were removing an actuator from a plug valve in the acetic acid unit. source.title: Martinez Renewable Fuels Fire

context.region: Martinez, California

event.summary: A fire erupted when a metal tube within a fired heater ruptured during the initial startup of a renewable diesel hydroprocessing unit. A lack of process flow due to valve misalignment combined with afterburning due to poor combustion conditions caused overheating of the tubes leading to the rupture and fire. Over 200,000 pounds of renewable diesel and 2,200 pounds of hydrogen were released. One employee received third-degree burns over 80 percent of his body and remained in critical condition for over six months. The incident resulted in approximately $350 million in damage.

actions_taken: API published revision of Tank Inspection, Repair, Alteration, and Reconstruction with Addendum 3 (API STD 653) in November 2023

event.summary: On July 17, 2001, an explosion occurred at the Motiva Enterprises refinery in Delaware City, Delaware when a spark from a contractor's cutting torch ignited flammable vapors emitted from a corroded sulfuric acid storage tank. The incident resulted in one fatality, eight injuries, and the release of 264,000 gallons of spent sulfuric acid. Approximately 99,000 gallons reached the Delaware River, causing significant environmental damage and killing aquatic life. Investigation revealed that the tank had not been inspected internally or externally for seven years and had significant corrosion in the shell and holes in the roof.
recommendations: Work with NACE International to develop API guidelines to inspect storage tanks containing fresh or spent H2SO4 at frequencies at least as often as those recommended in NACE Standard RP 0294-94

event.summary: On January 22, 2018, a blowout and rig fire occurred at Pryor Trust 0718 gas well number 1H-9 in Pittsburg County, Oklahoma, resulting in five worker fatalities. The workers were inside the driller's cabin on the rig floor and died from thermal burn injuries and smoke and soot inhalation. The blowout occurred approximately three-and-a-half hours after removing drill pipe out of the well. event.summary: The CSB reviewed and investigated numerous incidents where consequences escalated following a loss of containment due to the lack of effective remote isolation equipment. These incidents resulted in serious injuries, fatalities, environmental contamination, and severe damage to facilities. event.summary: On April 3, 2017, a pressure vessel (Semi-Closed Receiver) catastrophically failed at Loy-Lange Box Company in St. Louis, Missouri, causing a BLEVE. The explosion fatally injured one Loy-Lange employee and the launched vessel crashed through a nearby building roof, killing three members of the public. source.title: Kleen Energy Natural Gas Explosion

context.region: Middletown, Connecticut, USA

actions_taken: CSB issued Urgent Recommendation 2010-7-I-CT-UR3 to ASME
ASME revised B31.1 Section 100.1.4 in 2018 Edition to reference NFPA 56
B31.1 now requires consideration of NFPA Standard 56 for cleaning and purging of flammable gas systems
event.summary: On February 7, 2010, an explosion occurred during the planned cleaning of new fuel gas piping at Kleen Energy, a combined-cycle natural gas power plant under construction in Middletown, Connecticut. Workers were conducting a 'gas blow' whereby natural gas was forced through piping at high volume and pressure to remove debris. The natural gas and debris were vented into a congested outdoor area where the natural gas accumulated and found an ignition source, resulting in an explosion. The explosion resulted in six fatalities and injured at least 50 other personnel.
recommendations: Make appropriate changes to the 2010 version of Power Piping, ASME B31.1 to require the inherently safer fuel gas piping cleaning methodologies in favor of gas blows
Require the use of inherently safer alternatives such as air blows and pigging with air as the motive force in lieu of the use of flammable gas
Incorporate reference to NFPA 56, Standard for Fire and Explosion Prevention During Cleaning and Purging of Flammable Gas Piping Systems

event.summary: On December 7, 2009, a 50-foot pressure vessel used to manufacture synthetic crystals ruptured due to internal stress corrosion cracking at the NDK Crystal facility in Belvidere, Illinois. The vessel, located in an enclosed building, generated several projectiles when it ruptured that resulted in one fatality and one injury to members of the public, as well as significant property damage to the NDK Crystal facility and an adjacent business. The vessel operated at pressures greater than 10,000 psig and was made with SA-723 Grade 2 steel. The ASME Code sections applicable to the vessel did not include specific limitations of material thickness for heavy pressure vessels.
recommendations: Revise the ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code to include specific material thickness limitations for the design of pressure-containing components to ensure proper heat treatment and avoid environmentally induced damage mechanisms

source.title: Carbide Industries Electric Arc Furnace Explosion

context.region: Louisville, Kentucky, USA

actions_taken: CSB investigation conducted
Recommendations issued to NFPA and Carbide Industries
Carbide participated in conference calls with NFPA representatives
event.summary: On March 21, 2011, an electric arc furnace exploded at Carbide Industries in Louisville, Kentucky. Two workers sustained fatal injuries after hot gases and debris blown from the furnace broke through the double-pane reinforced glass window of the control room, which was located only 12 feet from the furnace. A third worker also sustained injuries. The investigation found that furnace overpressure events occurred a few times a year but were not investigated for root cause. Water leaks into the furnace could contribute to overpressure events, but Carbide did not have a robust inspection and mechanical integrity program. The close proximity of the control room to the furnace was not addressed despite previous overpressure events breaking control room windows.
recommendations: Modify the design and procedures for the electric arc furnace and related structures including the control room to comply with the NFPA standard
Establish a committee to evaluate and develop a standard that defines the safety requirements for electric arc furnaces operated with flammable materials and low oxygen atmospheres

event.summary: On May 31, 2017, an explosion and fire occurred at the Didion Milling facility in Cambria, Wisconsin. The fire spread throughout the facility resulting in multiple combustible dust explosions both within and external to the production equipment. event.summary: On September 21, 2020, during a planned shutdown at Evergreen Packaging's paper mill in Canton, North Carolina, a fire started inside an upflow tower when an electric heat gun being used to warm resin fell into a five-gallon bucket containing flammable resin. Two contractors working inside connected process vessels (upflow and downflow towers) in a pulp bleaching unit were fatally injured. The incident occurred during simultaneous maintenance operations by two contract companies.

Develop and implement a policy requiring involvement of emergency response personnel in planning and coordination of activities involving flammable materials in confined spaces

source.title: Third Coast Industries Petroleum Products Facility Fire

context.region: Friendswood, Texas

actions_taken: Firefighters arrived within minutes
100 nearby residents evacuated
Local school closed

event.summary: On May 1, 2002, a fire erupted at the Third Coast Industries facility near Friendswood, Texas. The facility blended and packaged motor oils, hydraulic oils, and other highly flammable liquids. Firefighters were unable to control the fire, which burned for 24 hours and consumed 1.2 million gallons of combustible and flammable liquids, destroying the entire site. The facility lacked fire detection equipment, was unstaffed at night, and had no water source for fire suppression. One hundred residents were evacuated and a local school was closed.
recommendations: Revise the International Fire Code to specify circumstances where automatic fire detection is needed for facilities not staffed around the clock
Narrow exemptions for Class IIIB liquids
Expand fire protection analysis requirements to include all areas of a facility where there may be flammable or combustible fire risks

source.title: US Ink Fire - Recommendation Status Change Summary

context.region: East Rutherford, New Jersey

actions_taken: CSB investigation conducted
Recommendations issued to New Jersey Department of Community Affairs
New Jersey Uniform Construction Code amended to regulate dust explosion hazards
event.summary: On October 9, 2012, a flash fire at the US Ink/Sun Chemical Corporation ink manufacturing facility in East Rutherford, New Jersey, injured seven workers, including three with third-degree burns. During start-up of a new dust collection system, a flammable mixture of hydrocarbons and combustible dusts accumulated in the ductwork and ignited. The CSB investigation found that improper design and operation of the dust collection system was a causal factor, and that minimum design criteria from NFPA standards had not been followed because the New Jersey Uniform Construction Code exempted process equipment from these requirements.
recommendations: Revise the exemption for manufacturing, production, and process equipment under the New Jersey Uniform Construction Code to require that equipment involved in processing, handling, or conveying combustible dust comply with the design and operating requirements of the current edition of the International Building Code

source.title: Combustible Dust Hazard Investigation - Recommendation Status Change

context.region: United States (44 states)

actions_taken: OSHA launched Combustible Dust National Emphasis Program on October 18, 2007
OSHA announced initiation of rulemaking on combustible dust on April 29, 2009

OSHA abandoned combustible dust rulemaking effort in summer 2017 citing resource constraints
event.summary: Between 1980 and 2005, 281 combustible dust incidents occurred across 44 states in various industries, resulting in 119 worker deaths and 718 injuries along with extensive property damage. After investigating three catastrophic dust explosions that killed 14 workers in 2003, the CSB conducted a comprehensive study and recommended OSHA issue a combustible dust standard. Despite regulatory enforcement and educational efforts, OSHA never issued the standard and abandoned rulemaking in 2017. The recommendation was superseded by a new recommendation from the 2023 Didion Milling Company investigation.

Base the standard on current NFPA dust explosion standards (including NFPA 654 and NFPA 484)
Include hazard assessment, engineering controls, housekeeping, building design, explosion protection, operating procedures, and worker training

event.summary: On May 4, 2009, an explosion and fire occurred at the Veolia ES Technical Solutions LLC facility in West Carrollton, Ohio. Tetrahydrofuran (THF), a flammable organic solvent, was released from a solvent recovery process in a tank farm area. Uncontrolled venting of THF allowed flammable vapors to accumulate to explosive concentrations outside the process equipment. The gas subsequently ignited, likely from two natural gas-fired boilers in a lab/operations building located 30 feet away. The initial blast injured four workers, two seriously. Multiple subsequent explosions significantly damaged the site, and nearby residences and businesses also sustained considerable damage.
recommendations: Revise control room siting guidelines to reflect the diversity of characteristics that Class 1B flammable liquids can exhibit (e.g., heavy vapor, and plant areas that provide congestion and confinement)

event.incident_type: Hydrocarbon Release and Fire with Secondary HF Release
actions_taken: Refinery Terminal Fire Company pumped salt water from Corpus Christi ship channel using firefighting barge

event.summary: On July 19, 2009, a hydrocarbon gas release occurred at the CITGO Corpus Christi East Refinery HF alkylation unit when violent shaking in process recycle piping broke two threaded connections. The shaking was caused by nearly complete flow blockage due to sudden failure of a control valve whose internal plug unthreaded from the valve stem. The hydrocarbon cloud ignited causing extensive damage and a multi-day fire. One employee was critically injured and another treated for possible HF exposure. The fire caused multiple failures releasing approximately 21 tons of HF, with the water mitigation system capturing most but an estimated 2-4 tons released to atmosphere. CITGO nearly exhausted its water supply during the incident, requiring emergency salt water pumping from the ship channel.
recommendations: Within 30 days, develop and initiate actions to ensure adequate water supply to the CITGO HF mitigation system
Every 30 days, report actions planned or completed to the Refinery Terminal Fire Company and Local Emergency Planning Committee
Within 60 days, complete a third-party audit of all CITGO HF alkylation unit operations in the United States as recommended by API RP 751
Share all audit results and corrective actions with all CITGO and contract employees whose work area includes the alkylation unit

The only existing bypass valve was manually operated and became inaccessible

highest expected efficiency of field systems like the one used by CITGO is likely 90 percent or less
CITGO has never conducted a safety audit of HF alkylation operations pursuant to API 751

event.summary: On 22 July 2023 at approximately 1240 hours, a fire occurred on VK 900 A Platform when diesel fuel from a tote tank on the top deck spilled onto the hot turbine compressor intake housing on the production deck below. The spill occurred during a diesel transfer operation when operators left the discharge hose in the containment skid during lunch break, causing a siphoning effect that overflowed the containment. Despite firefighting efforts by 6 POB using handheld and wheel unit extinguishers, the fire spread to the 8-man sleeper and grew beyond control. The PIC ordered evacuation at approximately 1320 hours. All personnel safely evacuated via M/V Landon James with no serious injuries. Two supply vessels extinguished the fire using water cannons. Estimated damage: $1.9 million.

supporting_text: According to Cox's report, the discharge hose was removed from the tote tank and placed within the containment skid, and the suction hose was left in the day tank while operators broke for lunch. It is suspected that the vacuum created by placing the discharge hose on the grating caused a siphoning effect from the day tank, resulting in diesel spilling out and overflowing the containment skid.

supporting_text: Investigators discovered two possible ignition sources. The first was the turbine compressor exhaust, which was situated below diesel tote tanks that were stored on the top deck directly above.
This caused the diesel to flow onto the hot turbine exhaust and exposed extension cord, which may have caused ignition.

controls.lod_basis: Equipment condition and maintenance

supporting_text: Evidence suggests that the extension cord running from the transfer pump to the 8-man sleeper could be another contributing cause to the incident. The extension cord going to the pump from the 8-man sleeper was laid on top of the grating. Signs of oxidation and decay were observed on the extension cord, suggesting that the cord had been stepped on while in use.
It is crucial to note that the extension cord's exposed wiring could have potentially caused ignition when the diesel spilled out of the containment skid.

controls.lod_basis: Active human monitoring during critical operations

supporting_text: According to Cox's report, the discharge hose was removed from the tote tank and placed within the containment skid, and the suction hose was left in the day tank while operators broke for lunch.
Human Performance Error – Not aware of hazards: Personnel left the hose used for the diesel transfer and extension cord out while they broke for lunch.

The PIC checked the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) computer and saw that the alarm was from the #1 turbine compressor.

The fire at the turbine compressor was eventually contained, but upstairs at the diesel tote tanks, the fire was burning out of control and quickly spread to the 8-man sleeper

POB continued using handheld and wheel unit fire extinguishers to fight the fire but were unsuccessful. After exhausting most of the fire extinguishers onboard, the PIC ordered all 6 POB to evacuate the platform.

The sludge in the day tank was causing the fuel filters on the generator powering the Firewater/Jockey Pump to clog. As a result, the Firewater/Jockey Pump was shut down at 1600 on 21 July 2023.

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - VK 915 Platform A Gas Release

context.region: Gulf of America, Viosca Knoll Block 915

event.summary: On November 24, 2024, at approximately 1710 hours, a 3/4 inch pipe nipple on the sight glass level bridle for Compressor #1 Suction Scrubber cracked and broke, causing a gas release at VK-915A (Marlin) Tension Leg Platform. The gas alarm activated, the Control Room Operator investigated and confirmed the release, and the Emergency Shutdown System shut in the platform. A platform muster was conducted with no injuries. The compressor and scrubber were isolated, the broken nipple was replaced within 30 minutes, and production resumed. Investigation determined the nipple failed due to fatigue cracking from multiple contributing factors including possible over-tightening during installation, vibration from the compressor, and excessive weight from the sight glass level bridle. The operator will submit a Management of Change to install additional support to prevent recurrence.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends that the Office of Incident Investigations should consider issuing a Safety Alert regarding the incident
Anadarko to submit Management of Change (MOC) to install additional support to the Compressor #1 Suction Scrubber sight glass level bridle to reduce weight and vibration on the nipple

event.summary: On 04 May 2025 at 0445 hours, the 178-foot supply vessel M/V Adriatic struck the Marlin Tension Leg Platform (VK 915 A) operated by Anadarko Petroleum Corporation. The vessel's captain was preparing paperwork for a drift test and not focused on navigation. The second captain had been given permission to leave the bridge, leaving no one actively steering the vessel. The bow contacted the Northwest pontoon and the right stern contacted the Southwest pontoon, damaging two production risers (Dorado and Crown and Anchor), a gas lift line, and firewater piping. The platform was manually ESD'd and production was shut in. No injuries or pollution occurred. Estimated damage exceeded $10 million.
recommendations: BSEE NOD recommends the Office of Incident Investigation (OII) issue a Safety Alert on this incident
Safety Alert should reach personnel who work on boats/vessels that service facilities, not just operators on the facility

event.summary: On December 2, 2024, at approximately 0830 hours, a gas release was discovered from subsea flowline pipeline segment 10688 at VK 989 Platform A during pressure testing of a newly replaced Subsea Control Module (SCM) pod. The gas release was detected by control room operators during testing, confirmed by ROV investigation showing gas bubbles at a 90-degree bend in the flowline. The operator immediately suspended testing and isolated the pipeline segment. The suspected cause is corrosion at a previous field repair weld that may have had imperfections. Repair options include installing an engineered clamp or replacing the damaged section with flexible pipe.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District has no recommendations for Office of Incident Investigations at this time

source.title: Structural Damage - Spinning Wrench Incident

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Vermillion Block 170

actions_taken: Assistant Driller evacuated to shore by boat on July 5, 2023 at 1:00 am

event.summary: On July 3, 2023, a spinning wrench rotated approximately 30 inches and struck the Assistant Driller in the hard hat and head while he was standing at the wrench controls during drilling operations on the Enterprise 264 rig. The wrench was improperly installed with only one back-up line instead of the two required by the manufacturer's user manual, allowing excessive rotational movement. The AD was diagnosed with a concussion and evacuated to shore two days after the incident. Investigation revealed the user manual was not readily available to rig personnel, and rig personnel were trained on the job without written procedures.
key_phrases: spinning wrench rotated and struck Assistant Driller
wrench not installed as manufacturer required
trained on the job without written procedures

Non-compliance with manufacturer specifications

controls.name: Two back-up cables to restrict rotational movement to 12 inches
controls.barrier_role: Prevent excessive rotation of spinning wrench
controls.lod_basis: Primary physical barrier to prevent hazardous equipment movement

supporting_text: Attach TWO back-up cables to the shackles provided at the rear of the wrench to restrict rotational movement to 12 inches in either direction
Investigators saw only one back-up line in use during the inspection
Only one back-up line was attached to the rear of the wrench
The wrench rotated clockwise approximately a quarter round, or approximately 30 inches

controls.barrier_role: Ensure proper mechanical connection per manufacturer design
controls.lod_basis: Primary mechanical connection as designed by manufacturer

supporting_text: Figure 1-1 of that same section showed the supplied shackle connected directly to the back-up line in the diagram
Investigators saw a second shackle attached to the supplied shackle with the back-up line attached to the second shackle during the inspection
A second shackle was attached to the supplied shackle

Investigators received the User Manual for the spinning wrench July 12, 2023, by email

source.title: Explosion and Fire on Liftboat Brazos at Vermilion Block 170 A

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Vermilion Block 170

actions_taken: General alarm sounded
Non-essential workers mustered
Fire extinguished in 15 minutes using fire water hose and wheeled fire extinguishers
First aid provided to injured workers
USCG contacted for evacuation
Both injured workers evacuated by helicopter to medical facility
Surface Safety Valves 1 and 2 automatically closed
Subsurface safety valve manually closed with wireline hydraulic hand pump
event.summary: On August 11, 2024, at approximately 7:10 p.m., an explosion and fires occurred on the deck of the liftboat Brazos at Vermilion Block 170 A during well cleanup and test operations. Two PTS workers were injured with second-degree burns. The incident was caused by gas escaping through improperly latched hatches on a 500-barrel atmospheric tank, creating a flammable atmosphere that was drawn into a rental diesel generator. The generator's faulty electronic control module prevented the automatic air intake shutdown device from functioning when the engine oversped, leading to ignition of the gas plume. Contributing factors included lack of written procedures, inadequate hazard analysis, poor maintenance of tank hatch O-rings, and calm wind conditions that allowed gas accumulation.
recommendations: BSEE Lake Charles District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations issue a Safety Alert/Bulletin regarding this incident

threats.name: Gas release from improperly sealed tank hatches
Gas accumulation in calm wind conditions
Ignition source from diesel generator

controls.name: 500-barrel tank hatch latching system
controls.barrier_role: Prevent gas release from tank
controls.lod_basis: Primary physical barrier to contain gas

supporting_text: The three 24-inch hatches on the 500-barrel tank were not properly latched allowing gas to escape through the unsealed hatches

Each of the 24-inch hatch covers at the top of the tank was inspected, and the O-rings were found absent of fresh grease. The O-rings were then removed from the groove and found to have visible cracks and signs of deterioration. Corrosion was also observed on the seating face of the hatch cover

controls.name: Tank hatch O-ring maintenance and inspection
controls.barrier_role: Ensure gas-tight seal on tank hatches
controls.lod_basis: Maintenance program to ensure integrity of primary containment

supporting_text: The O-rings on the hatches were not maintained, as they were absent of grease, showed visible cracks, and signs of deterioration

BSEE investigators inquired about the process for inspecting the 500-barrel tank at the well site location. The PTS Manager explained that the atmospheric vent and the pressure safety valve are removed for transportation purposes, and then reinstalled once on location. Additionally, the three hatches are re-tightened once on-site due to rough roads and other events that could loosen the latch-bolts during the transportation process

controls.name: Written procedures for tank commissioning
controls.barrier_role: Ensure proper setup and verification of equipment
controls.lod_basis: Procedural control to guide proper execution of critical tasks

supporting_text: BSEE investigators asked the PTS Manager if there were written procedures for prepping the 500-barrel tank or written procedures for draining fluids from the separator after the well test is completed, the PTS Manager responded that there are no written procedures
There were no written procedures for commissioning or decommissioning the temporary well cleanup and test equipment

controls.name: Written procedures for separator draining operations
controls.barrier_role: Control rate and method of gas release during draining
controls.lod_basis: Procedural control to manage hazardous operations

supporting_text: When BSEE investigators asked about written procedures for draining fluids out of the separator after the well test, the PTS Day Supervisor admitted there were none in place
The PTS Day Supervisor explained that the common practice for PTS workers was to hold down the level controllers for the water and oil until gas blow-by was heard

controls.name: Job Safety Analysis (JSA) and hazard identification
controls.barrier_role: Identify and control hazards before work begins
controls.lod_basis: Risk assessment to identify and mitigate hazards

supporting_text: On the morning of August 11, 2024, at approximately 5:30 a.m., Gulf held a day shift pre-tour safety meeting with PTS, which included a job safety analysis (JSA) and a sequence of planned events for the day

There was an inadequate hazard analysis conducted for this situation. None of the JSAs mentioned the potential for a large amount of gas to be released during the emptying of fluids from the separator

controls.name: Personal gas detectors (H2S only)
controls.barrier_role: Detect presence of hazardous gas
controls.lod_basis: Detection system to alert personnel of gas presence

supporting_text: BSEE investigators also asked about the presence of gas detection equipment on the work deck during the incident. The PTS Day Supervisor confirmed that all PTS workers were equipped with personal gas detectors provided by PTS. Upon inspection, BSEE investigators found that the detectors were Honeywell BW Clip H2S detectors designed specifically for detecting the presence of H2S gas only

controls.name: Generator automatic air intake shutdown device
controls.barrier_role: Prevent diesel engine from ingesting flammable gas
controls.lod_basis: Automatic safety system to prevent ignition source

supporting_text: The generator's faulty electronic control module prevented the air intake shut-off valve from automatically shutting down the engine when it reached its over-frequency setpoint
The control module displayed alarm codes for Emergency Stop, Air Flap Closed, and Gen Over frequency Shutdown in the event log

However, when they tried to activate the manual electronic emergency stop push button on the exterior of the enclosure the air intake valve failed to close. The technicians then attempted to shut the air intake valve electronically, simulating an automatic emergency shutdown (ESD), but were unsuccessful

controls.name: Generator control module maintenance and testing
controls.barrier_role: Ensure reliability of automatic shutdown systems
controls.lod_basis: Maintenance program to ensure safety system integrity

supporting_text: The electronic control module was removed, and upon inspection, the circuit board showed signs of deterioration and delamination

BSEE investigators inquired about the process of preparing the generator for rental. The technician explained that the generator was serviced, cleaned, and all settings in the control module were verified. It was also mentioned that the ESD was tested before dispatch. The BSEE investigators requested copies of testing documentation, but the technician stated that the tests were not documented

When BSEE investigators asked about how the generator was tested on-site the technician admitted that the automatic electronic ESD could not be tested without a technician, however the manual electronic emergency stop button could be tested

controls.name: Area classification and equipment placement
controls.barrier_role: Separate ignition sources from flammable atmospheres
controls.lod_basis: Design control to prevent ignition sources in hazardous areas

supporting_text: The generator was located outside the classified area as depicted on the area classification drawing
The distance from the generator to the closest flange on the 500-barrel tank was twelve feet and one inch
The calm wind conditions allowed a gas plume to accumulate near the 500-barrel tank and generator, creating a hazardous atmosphere on the work deck

controls.name: 500-barrel tank atmospheric vent with flame arrestor
controls.barrier_role: Safely vent gas and prevent flame propagation into tank
controls.lod_basis: Passive safety device to prevent ignition of tank contents

supporting_text: BSEE investigators noticed an atmospheric vent with a flame arrestor above the 500-barrel tank, and no visual fire damage was observed
The flame arrestor had a dent to the exterior housing; however, the element showed no fire damage and appeared clean and free of obstructions

controls.name: 500-barrel tank pressure safety valve (20 psi)
controls.barrier_role: Prevent overpressure of tank
controls.lod_basis: Passive safety device to protect tank integrity

supporting_text: A pressure safety valve with a set point of 20 psi was visually inspected and showed no signs of fire damage

controls.name: Emergency shutdown system (pneumatic panel and valves)
controls.barrier_role: Isolate well and stop flow in emergency
controls.lod_basis: Automatic safety system to stop hazardous flow

supporting_text: During the interviews, BSEE investigators were informed by the Gulf representative that both Surface Safety Valve 1 and Surface Safety Valve 2 automatically closed when the pneumatic panel emergency shutdown was activated. The subsurface safety valve was manually closed with the wireline hydraulic hand pump
BSEE investigators observed that the master group mode selector switch on the pneumatic panel was in-service with all relays closed and all gauges showing zero pressure

controls.name: Fire and gas detection system (emergency shutdown fire loop)
controls.barrier_role: Detect fire and activate emergency shutdown
controls.lod_basis: Detection system to initiate automatic response

supporting_text: The polyethylene tubing line for the emergency shutdown fire loop had melted near the 500-barrel tank

controls.name: General alarm system
controls.barrier_role: Alert personnel to emergency
controls.lod_basis: Warning system to initiate emergency response

supporting_text: The general alarm sounded on the liftboat, and non-essential workers reported to the muster area

controls.name: Muster and evacuation procedures
controls.barrier_role: Protect personnel during emergency
controls.lod_basis: Emergency response procedure to minimize personnel exposure

supporting_text: The general alarm sounded on the liftboat, and non-essential workers reported to the muster area

controls.name: Fire fighting equipment and response
controls.barrier_role: Extinguish fire and limit damage
controls.lod_basis: Active fire suppression to control consequences

supporting_text: Workers from Laredo, PTS, and Gulf responded to the fire, which was extinguished in approximately 15 minutes using at least one fire water hose from the liftboat and four wheeled fire extinguishers on the work deck
BSEE investigators observed two 33-gallon foam-wheeled fire extinguishers discharged as well as two 300-pound purple-K wheeled fire extinguishers discharged on the work deck

controls.name: First aid and medical response
controls.barrier_role: Provide immediate medical care to injured personnel
controls.lod_basis: Emergency medical response to minimize injury severity

supporting_text: Two PTS workers sustained second degree burns to their face, neck, and hands requiring medical attention. They received first aid in the galley of the liftboat while waiting for evacuation

controls.name: Emergency evacuation and medical transport
controls.barrier_role: Transport injured personnel to medical facilities
controls.lod_basis: Emergency response to provide definitive medical care

supporting_text: The USCG arrived at 10:51 p.m. and hoisted both injured workers into the helicopter, transferring them to a medical facility in Lafayette by 12:14 a.m. on August 12, 2024

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - VR-369 Alpha Platform Pressure Release Injury

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - Vermilion Area Block 369

event.incident_type: Uncontrolled pressure release from well tree
actions_taken: First aid provided with eye wash bottles, clean bandages and Advil

IP transported to Lafayette General Hospital at 1:34 AM
BSEE onsite investigation conducted April 12, 2024
Interviews conducted with personnel and contractor employees
event.summary: On April 4, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM, a Cajun Cutters welder was injured when unexpected gas pressure was released from the top of well A-15 tree during removal of a tree cap adapter flange. The worker was impacted in the left eye and left side of face by the pressure release. The incident occurred during temporary production piping reconfiguration work for pipeline depressurization. The worker had been on duty for 15.5 hours. Lockout/Tagout procedures were not properly implemented to ensure positive isolation of all well tree valves. The injured person required medical evacuation and sustained partial permanent hearing loss and eye injuries requiring ongoing treatment.

unexpected release of pressure from the top of the well tree
Lockout/Tagout was not implemented to ensure positive isolation
operator with no previous platform specific experience
IP was on duty for 15.5 hours
No safe working surfaces were provided

hazards.name: Pressurized hydrocarbon gas in well tree

controls.name: Lockout/Tagout of well tree valves

No record of Lockout/Tagout was provided to the BSEE investigators for the automatic surface safety valve

There were no written procedures provided to the BSEE investigators, nor written instructions provided to personnel that would specify which valves had been isolated and ensure all pressure had been removed

controls.lod_basis: Pre-job hazard identification

supporting_text: Cajun Cutters' JSA discussed 'not following procedure and stored energy as potential hazards' and '100% containment and checking for pressure' as steps to eliminate hazards
The scaffold builder (GSSI), who was assisting with the job, was not listed on the JSA
No site specific JSA was prepared discussing job steps or body positioning

controls.name: Pressure verification before opening well tree
controls.barrier_role: Verify zero energy state before breaking containment
controls.lod_basis: Critical verification step

supporting_text: At approximately 2:27 PM the platform was shut in by the platform operators and pressure from the tie-in points was bled to zero. After verifying the pressure was removed, Cajun Cutters removed a section of pipeline piping
Witnesses stated that the A-15 well had 800 psig of pressure at the top of the well tree before the pressure was bled to zero above the Surface Safety Valve (SSV)
Renaissance reported that trapped gas pressure was released from a valve cavity but did not identify which valve the pressure was released from

controls.barrier_role: Automatic isolation of well in emergency conditions
