supporting_text: A recent Surface Controlled Sub-Surface Safety Valve (SCSSV) test was collected indicating the A-15 well had a shut-in tubing pressure of 1195 psig
Witnesses stated that the A-15 well had 800 psig of pressure at the top of the well tree before the pressure was bled to zero above the Surface Safety Valve (SSV)

The night shift operator's duties included routine production operations of the platform, including maintaining the incoming production from VR-408A

Statements included such comments as 'The tree blew up with pressure,' 'It was so loud,' and 'I heard what sounded like a gas release @~10:30 PM. I got out of bed and got dressed.'

This position placed the top of the well tree at the IP and helper's midsection with them looking down at the tree cap

source.title: Fire Incident during Construction Operations at HI A 379 B Platform

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, HI Area Block A 379

actions_taken: Work stopped immediately
Alarm sounded
Emergency Shut Down (ESD) initiated
Fire extinguished using one 125-pound ABC wheeled fire extinguisher, two 30-pound fire extinguishers, and three firewater hose reels

event.summary: On February 21, 2024, at approximately 1349 hours, a fire occurred at the HI A 379 B platform operated by W&T Offshore during construction operations to replace corroded deck plating. While a construction fitter was grinding freshly laid welds, sparks migrated through two layers of protective fire blanket barriers into a chemical/methanol storage area approximately six feet away, igniting flammable materials. The fire was extinguished using multiple fire extinguishers and hose reels. The facility was shut down via ESD. Investigation revealed that flammable materials should have been removed per JSA requirements rather than relying on fire blanket barriers.
recommendations: All approved welding and burning plans should state the proper Code of Federal Regulations must be followed
Ensure flammable or combustible items are removed from hot work areas as per JSA requirements
Improve pre-job safety meetings to ensure all written procedures are discussed and followed
Resolve contradictions between approved General Welding and Burning Plan and Hot Work Checklist
key_phrases: sparks migrated through two layers of protective fire blanket barriers
Remove all FLAMMABLE OR COMBUSTABLE ITEMS
no discussion or consideration was given to the two written requirements
swirling winds generated during a helicopter landing operation

The construction crew elected to use the third control measure of the W&T Offshore Hot Work Checklist, which was erecting fire blanket barriers between the work area and the chemical storage area
Utilizing the mentioned control measure did not eliminate the hazard

controls.lod_basis: Primary administrative control to eliminate hazard

supporting_text: The Zealous Job Safety Analysis (JSA) clearly states 'Remove all FLAMMABLE OR COMBUSTABLE ITEMS, Make sure no Hydrocarbons are present.'
Storage and chemical tote tanks could have been moved to another area
Written procedures in submitted documents clearly states to remove hydrocarbons prior to hot work commencing
no discussion or consideration was given to the two written requirements cited in the Zealous JSA

This line item was checked as yes.
The construction crew elected to use the third control measure of the W&T Offshore Hot Work Checklist
While reviewing W&T approved General Welding and Burning Plan this document contradicts the W&T Hot Work Checklist

it is the responsibility of the PIC and Task Supervisor (Construction Foreman) to ensure control measures or in place and effective

source.title: Crane Incident - West Cameron 33 Platform

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - West Cameron Block 33

event.top_event: Wire Rope Sling Failure During Lifting Operations
actions_taken: IP transferred to derrick barge in personnel basket
First aid provided by medic
Medevac helicopter called at 5:45 pm
Motor Vessel Hannah Ray evacuated IP at 9:15 pm
IP received 16 stitches and treatment for C6 vertebrae fracture
event.summary: On August 10, 2023, at approximately 5:15 pm, during decommissioning operations at West Cameron 33 Platform, a 2.5-ton wire rope sling parted while lifting a water abrasive cutter from a 48-inch caisson. The abrasive cutter had hung up in the caisson and was being re-lifted when it hung up again simultaneously with a wave surge. The parted sling struck an Offshore Technical Services employee on the head and neck, causing a forehead laceration requiring 16 stitches and a C6 vertebrae fracture. The incident occurred in 5-7 foot seas with the injured person standing next to the open caisson without fall protection. The JSA did not address dynamic loading from adverse sea conditions or specify the maximum lift weight relative to sling capacity.
key_phrases: stay well clear of suspended loads

threats.name: Dynamic Loading from Wave Surge
Load Hang-Up in Caisson
Inadequate Lift Planning
Personnel in Suspended Load Zone

consequences.name: Personnel Injury - Head and Neck Trauma

controls.name: Job Safety and Environmental Analysis (JSA)
controls.barrier_role: Hazard identification and risk assessment
controls.lod_basis: Planning and design control

supporting_text: In the JSA, the total weight to be lifted was not mentioned nor were the limitations of the slings described
The JSA did not have written threats of the dynamic loading of waves during the lift or the lift hanging up in the 48-inch caisson
The JSA did not address the possible hazards with adverse sea conditions with sea states at 5 to 7 feet

controls.name: Wire Rope Sling Capacity and Inspection
controls.barrier_role: Equipment integrity barrier
controls.lod_basis: Physical barrier to prevent overload

supporting_text: The vertical safe working limit is 2.5 tons for all five slings in the sling assembly below the tool lift beam
The maximum lift for retrieving the abrasive cutter was 2.5 tons, which was the safe working limit of the wire rope slings
A 2.5-ton wire rope sling in the abrasive cutter lifting arrangement parted
a two foot long, single-leg vertical sling was parted at the eye of the sling and the thimble and sleeve were missing

controls.barrier_role: Operational control to halt unsafe operations
controls.lod_basis: Monitoring and intervention control

supporting_text: The JSA listed adverse wind and sea conditions as a Potential Hazard, and the recommendation to eliminate or reduce potential hazards was to 'Call All Stop If Necessary'
During the lift, the abrasive cutter hung up in the caisson. An all-stop was not called to address any new threats
An all-stop was not called to address any new threats after the abrasive cutter hung up in the 48-inch caisson the first time

controls.name: Exclusion Zone for Suspended Loads

source.title: Crane Structural Damage - West Delta 152 A Platform

context.region: Gulf of America, West Delta Block 152

actions_taken: Secured crane boom with ratchets and straps to prevent further falling
Removed boom completely and transported to third-party crane service facility
Conducted laboratory analysis of failed boom cable
Updated crane inspection policy to require annual removal of sheaves and sheave pins
event.summary: On 27 August 2025 at 1045 hours, a crane boom cable separated during a dynamic lift of an 8,000-pound Power Pack from a motor vessel to the WD-152 A platform. The crane boom fell uncontrollably, striking platform handrails and the motor vessel stern. Investigation revealed a seized bearing in the boom cable bridle sheave assembly caused the sheave pin to wear down approximately 1/2 inch. The cable cut through the Nylatron sheave material until it contacted the hardened bearing race, then cut through the sheave side, ultimately failing under slow strain. A small amount of hydraulic fluid entered the Gulf of America from broken hoses and fittings. No injuries occurred. Damage totaled $125,000.
recommendations: BSEE New Orleans District recommends the Office of Incident Investigations consider issuing a Safety Alert regarding the incident
Update crane safe work practices to require annual removal of sheaves and sheave pins for inspection
Incorporate sheave pin removal procedures into crane inspection training documentation
Enhance inspection procedures to identify bearing wear and sheave pin degradation
key_phrases: sheave pin not removed during inspection

threats.name: Bearing seizure in boom cable bridle sheave
Sheave pin wear due to failed bearing
Cable cutting through sheave material
Boom cable failure under strain

consequences.name: Damage to motor vessel stern and jump deck
Hydraulic fluid release to Gulf of America
Potential personnel injury from falling equipment

controls.name: Annual crane inspection
controls.barrier_role: Detection and verification of crane component integrity
controls.lod_basis: Periodic inspection to detect degradation before failure

supporting_text: The last crane inspection, other than a crane pre-use, that was performed on the crane prior to the incident was an annual inspection on 01 August 2025.
During this inspection, the Crane Inspector checked off in his paperwork that the bridle sheaves and boom cable were in good condition at the time of the inspection.
The crane inspector stated he was not required to remove the sheave pin per company policies and the API RP 2D Sixth edition that they follow.

Because the sheave pins were not removed during past annual inspections, there is no definitive conclusion as to whether the pin was worn prior to or after the annual inspection performed on 01 August 2025.

controls.name: Sheave bearing and pin inspection procedure
controls.barrier_role: Detection of bearing and pin wear
controls.lod_basis: Inspection procedure to identify component degradation

supporting_text: The crane inspector stated that during the inspection of the bridle sheaves, he lowered the bridle to the crane boom and provided slack in the boom cable to allow him to move the sheaves freely. He then rolled/turned the sheaves to ensure they moved freely without cable tension.
The Inspector also stated that he did not remove the sheave pin to inspect it.
The third-party crane service provided their sheave inspection training guide, and the training did not specify the removal of the sheave pin during sheave inspections.
Neither method recognizes pulling the bridle sheave pin as part of the inspection.

controls.name: Crane load chart and Safe Working Load limits
controls.barrier_role: Prevention of overloading
controls.lod_basis: Operational limit to prevent excessive loading

supporting_text: The crane operator was operating the crane at 61–65-degree boom angles when the incident occurred.

The crane's load chart states that at a 61-degree boom angle, the crane's dynamic Safe Working Load (SWL) is 12,200 pounds, placing the load being lifted well within the crane's capacity at the angle during the time of the incident.
The Crane Operator notified the MV Captain by radio that his next lift was going to be a Power Pack weighing approximately 8,000 pounds.

controls.name: Crane pull test verification
controls.barrier_role: Verification of crane structural capacity
controls.lod_basis: Testing to verify equipment performance

supporting_text: The Crane Inspector also performed a pull test on the crane on 02 August 2025 which successfully pulled 30,900 pounds at a 74-degree boom angle and a 25-foot radius according to the inspector's paperwork.

controls.name: Crane pre-use inspection
controls.barrier_role: Detection of visible defects before operation
controls.lod_basis: Pre-operational check to identify obvious defects

supporting_text: The last crane inspection, other than a crane pre-use, that was performed on the crane prior to the incident was an annual inspection on 01 August 2025.

controls.name: Sheave bearing lubrication
controls.barrier_role: Prevention of bearing seizure through maintenance
controls.lod_basis: Preventive maintenance to ensure component function

supporting_text: He stated that he greased the sheaves by using the greasing points on the sheave pin.

controls.name: Crane operator positioning and communication
controls.barrier_role: Safe lift execution and vessel positioning
controls.lod_basis: Operational control to ensure safe lift conditions

supporting_text: After lowering the cutting box to the MV, the Crane Operator notified the MV Captain by radio that his next lift was going to be a Power Pack weighing approximately 8,000 pounds.
The MV then moved too close to the platform for the Crane Operator to comfortably make the lift, so the Crane Operator asked the MV captain to move forward (away from the platform).
Once the MV was positioned where the Crane Operator felt safe making the lift, the Deckhand then hooked the main line stinger to the Power Pack that was to be lifted.

controls.name: Emergency crane boom securing procedure
controls.barrier_role: Prevention of further damage after initial failure
controls.lod_basis: Post-incident action to prevent escalation

supporting_text: After the incident occurred and all personnel were safe, Renaissance decided to secure the crane boom that was hanging off the side of the platform with ratchets and straps.
This was performed to reduce the possibility of the crane boom or other components falling into the Gulf of America.
Later, Renaissance removed the boom completely to prevent any possibilities of the crane boom falling.

controls.name: Personnel safety positioning during crane operations
controls.barrier_role: Prevention of personnel injury from falling objects
controls.lod_basis: Operational practice to keep personnel clear of hazard zones

supporting_text: There were no injuries caused by the incident but there was damage to the platform handrails, the crane, and the MV.

source.title: BSEE Accident Investigation Report - West Delta 73 Gas Leak

context.region: Gulf of Mexico - West Delta Block 73

actions_taken: Emergency Shutdown System (ESD) activated
All 26 personnel mustered upwind at quarters structure (73Q)
Sheltered in place due to weather conditions
Notified National Response Center (NRC#1360214)

Diesel generator started at D platform

event.summary: On 17 February 2023 at approximately 0315 hours, a gas leak occurred on a 12-inch gas pipeline riser (PSN 759) approximately 5-7 feet above the water line at the WD 73AT production platform. The ESD was activated, shutting down the entire facility. All 26 personnel on board mustered upwind at the quarters structure and sheltered in place due to severe weather conditions (5-8 foot seas, 20-30 knot winds with gusts to 40 knots). The pipeline was bled down from 1080 psi to 0 psi. A light non-recoverable sheen (2.56 miles long, 300 feet wide) was observed during overflight. Investigation determined the leak was caused by inadequate preventative maintenance, with repairs identified in a 2015 Level 2 survey never completed, and inadequate inspection methods (drone survey on 15 Feb 2023 insufficient, no intelligent PIG inspection conducted).
key_phrases: intelligent Pipeline Inspection Gauge not used

threats.name: Pipeline Riser Corrosion/Degradation
Concrete Coating Damage at Waterline
Internal Pipeline Defects (Metal Loss, Corrosion, Cracks)

supporting_text: The most recent Level 1 survey was completed on 15 February 2023 and showed no issues or damage to the PSN 759 riser

BSEE also identified an inadequate Level 1 survey that was conducted on 15 February 2023. During the survey, a drone was used to inspect PSN 759 and did not provide sufficient examination of the pipeline

controls.name: Level 2 Pipeline Inspection Survey with Diver Inspection

controls.lod_basis: Periodic detailed inspection to identify defects requiring repair

supporting_text: The Level 2 survey completed on 11 December 2015 inspected the Cathodic Potential (CP) and Riser/J-Tube
According to the report, the diver was unable to repair damage at the waterline due to rough seas. The riser is concrete coated, and the damage noted was to the concrete coating

supporting_text: Cox could not provide documentation stating the repairs at the waterline were ever made

BSEE's investigation determined that Cox failed to properly maintain PSN 759. This is supported by Cox's inability to provide documents showing the repairs at the waterline (noted in the 2015 Level 2 survey) were ever made
Equipment Failure – Inadequate preventative maintenance: Lessee failed to provide adequate preventative maintenance that could have identified and prevented the gas release

supporting_text: Another contributing factor to the incident discovered in BSEE's investigation was the lack of use of an intelligent Pipeline Inspection Gauge (PIG) with technology capabilities of magnetic flux leakage (MFL), ultrasound, and/or calipers to measure the inside geometry of the pipeline. Using this type of PIG could have identified metal loss, corrosion, cracks, or any other contributing factors within the pipeline that lead up to the gas release

source.title: BSEE Gulf of America Region Accident Investigation Report - WD 90 B Platform

context.region: Gulf of America, West Delta Block 90

actions_taken: Full platform evacuation
Muster on E platform
Crown valve closed on B20 surface tree

event.summary: On April 21, 2025, at approximately 19:30hrs CDT, the West Delta 90 B platform experienced a loss of well control during Plug and Abandonment operations on well B020. While pumping fluid down the tubing to equalize pressure across a downhole plug, approximately 20 barrels of oil and gas were released from a leak at the starter head flange and 10-3/4 x 20 surface casing annulus. The uncontrolled release led to full platform evacuation. The incident resulted from a breach at the spooling head and failure within the tubing string that enabled hydraulic communication between tubing and annulus. Contributing factors included inadequate pre-job planning, failure to incorporate historical well data showing prior leakage issues, and lack of hazard assessment before continuing operations after initial leak detection.
recommendations: The BSEE New Orleans District has no recommendations at this time

lack of detailed knowledge regarding specific well history
no stopping point to discuss potential hazards
breakdown in communication between successive work crews
failed to account for prior well activity

supporting_text: Once the starter head spool was found to be leaking, there was no stopping point by the crew to discuss what potential hazards may exists and how to prevent/mitigate this risk before continuing with the abandon procedure

the spooling head had a documented history of leakage, and that the DS plug had been installed in response to operators detecting gas emissions at the surface
This prior information was not integrated into the current operational planning

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Overboard Drilling Fluid Discharge

context.region: Gulf of Mexico, East Breaks Block 699

actions_taken: MPD system put into Flow Control mode
MPD pressure control valves shut by MPD operator
Well shut in using BOP upper annular at 05:20 AM
Kick circulated out using Drillers Method
Drilling fluid returns examined by Mud Engineer
event.summary: On November 16, 2022, at 05:11 AM, approximately twelve barrels of Synthetic Based Mud (SBM) were discharged into the Gulf of Mexico from the Diamond Offshore drillship West Vela during exploration drilling operations at 25,000 feet depth. A saltwater kick of fifty-eight barrels occurred below the base of salt, causing the Managed Pressure Drilling (MPD) system Surface Back Pressure to exceed 1,300 psi, triggering Pressure Relief Valves that were lined up to discharge overboard instead of to the flowline. The well was successfully shut in with shut-in drill pipe pressure of 1,600 psi, and the kick was circulated out. The MPD system was not designed to control influxes greater than five barrels.
recommendations: MPD procedures and hole section influx management envelope matrix should include a differential flow threshold to inform the Driller how to respond when using MPD

When using PCVs for MPD, ensure modeling is performed to determine: 1) optimal PCV setpoints with down hole pumps on based on maximum kick intensity; 2) maximum PCV setpoint based on required SBP for connections with down hole pumps off
Set maximum PCV pressure to protect against PRVs from opening based on a maximum flow rate for the selected setpoint
Review FMCA for plugging downstream of the MPD choke to confirm the correct PRV set point should limit system to pressure rating of equipment upstream of the choke

Review the latest version of the flow control software that responds to influxes in step changes and switches the MPD from Flow Control to SBP mode when the high-pressure limit is reached to allow the chokes to open before the PCV limit is reached

well shut in by BOP upper annular
MPD diverter valve lined up overboard

source.title: Accident Investigation Report - Structural Damage - Pipe Laydown System Failure

event.summary: On January 7, 2023, during drilling operations on the Transocean Deepwater Atlas drillship, a 6-5/8 inch drill pipe joint weighing 60.78 lbs/ft was dropped 58 feet onto the pipe skate when the Pipe Laydown System (PLS) failed to maintain grip. The PLS only engaged the roller jaw while the centralizer and gripper arms did not fully grip due to a hydraulic leak. The Assistant Driller could not visually confirm proper grip due to obstructed view and relied solely on the control screen which gave no indication of the partial grip or unintended movement. All personnel were in the safe step back area and no injuries occurred.
recommendations: Install camera for visual confirmation of proper grip on tubulars
Get confirmation of proper grip from Floorhands in safe step back area before proceeding
Manufacturer to address feedback of unintended movement of PLS via alarm on Assistant Driller's screen
